cents: (money) A subunit of currency equal to one-hundredth of the main unit of currency in many countries. Symbol: ¢.

cosmo: A cosmopolitan, a cocktail containing vodka, triple sec, lime juice and cranberry juice.

coupe: An ice cream dessert; the glass it is served in.

coups: A quick, brilliant, and highly successful act.

covid: Short for COVID-19, the disease caused by Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus.

cowed: (chiefly in the passive voice) To intimidate; to daunt the spirits or courage of.

craps: A game of gambling, or chance, where the players throw dice to make scores and avoid crap.

crazy: An insane or eccentric person; a crackpot.

creep: To move slowly with the abdomen close to the ground.

crews: A pen for livestock such as chickens or pigs

crisp: A thin slice of fried potato eaten as a snack.

croak: A faint, harsh sound made in the throat.

exeat: A license or permit for absence from a college or a religious house (such as a monastery).

exine: The outer layer of a pollen grain or spore; the exosporium

exist: (stative) to be; have existence; have being or reality

exits: An act of going out or going away, or leaving; a departure.

extra: Something additional, such as an item above and beyond the ordinary school curriculum, or added to the usual charge on a bill.

exude: To discharge through pores or incisions, as moisture or other liquid matter; to give out.

exult: To rejoice; to be very happy, especially in triumph.

exurb: A residential area beyond the suburbs.

eyras: A slender, reddish-yellow wild cat (Puma yagouaroundi eyra) ranging from southern Brazil to Texas.

eyres: A journey in circuit of certain itinerant judges called justices in eyre (or in itinere).

eyrie: The nest of a bird of prey.

eyrir: A subdivision of currency, equal to one hundredth of an Icelandic króna

fable: A fictitious narrative intended to enforce some useful truth or precept, usually with animals, etc. as characters; an apologue. Prototypically, Aesop's Fables.

faced: (of a person or animal) To position oneself or itself so as to have one's face closest to (something).

facer: An unexpected and stunning blow or defeat.

faces: The front part of the head of a human or other animal, featuring the eyes, nose and mouth, and the surrounding area.

facet: Any one of the flat surfaces cut into a gem.

facia: A wide band of material covering the ends of roof rafters, sometimes supporting a gutter in steep-slope roofing, but typically it is a border or trim in low-slope roofing.

facts: Something actual as opposed to invented.

faded: To grow weak; to lose strength; to decay; to perish gradually; to wither, as a plant.

fades: A golf shot that (for the right-handed player) curves intentionally to the right. See slice, hook, draw.

fadge: To be suitable (with or to something).

faery: The realm of faerie; enchantment, illusion.

fagot: (collective) A bundle of sticks or brushwood intended to be used for fuel tied together for carrying. (Some sources specify that a faggot is tied with two bands or withes, whereas a bavin is tied with just one.)

fairs: A community gathering to celebrate and exhibit local achievements.

fairy: The realm of faerie; enchantment, illusion.

faith: A trust or confidence in the intentions or abilities of a person, object, or ideal from prior empirical evidence.

faked: To cheat; to swindle; to steal; to rob.

fakes: Something which is not genuine, or is presented fraudulently.

fakir: A faqir, owning no personal property and usually living solely off alms.

falls: The act of moving to a lower position under the effect of gravity.

false: One of two options on a true-or-false test.

fanal: A lighthouse, or the apparatus placed in it for giving light.

fango: Mud from the thermal springs at Battaglia in Italy, used to treat certain medical complaints such as gout and rheumatism.

fangs: A long, pointed canine tooth used for biting and tearing flesh

faqir: A religious mendicant who owns no personal property.

farad: In the International System of Units, the derived unit of electrical capacitance; the capacitance of a capacitor in which one coulomb of charge causes a potential difference of one volt across the capacitor. Symbol: F

farce: A style of humor marked by broad improbabilities with little regard to regularity or method.

farcy: A contagious disease of horses, resembling glanders

fards: Force of movement, impetus, rush; hence, a violent onset.

fares: A going; journey; travel; voyage; course; passage.

farls: A quarter of a thin oatmeal or flour cake.

farms: A place where agricultural and similar activities take place, especially the growing of crops or the raising of livestock.

farse: A vernacular paraphrase inserted into Latin liturgy.

farts: An emission of digestive gases from the anus; a flatus.

fasts: A train that calls at only some stations it passes between its origin and destination, typically just the principal stations

fatal: A fatality; an event that leads to death.

fated: To foreordain or predetermine, to make inevitable.

fates: The presumed cause, force, principle, or divine will that predetermines events.

fatty: Containing, composed of, or consisting of fat.

fatwa: A legal opinion, decree or ruling issued by a mufti or other Islamic lawyer.

faugh: An exclamation of contempt, or of disgust, especially for a smell.

fault: A defect; something that detracts from perfection.

fauna: Animals considered as a group; especially those of a particular country, region, time.

fauns: A woodland creature with pointed ears, legs, and short horns of a goat and a fondness for unrestrained revelry.

favor: A kind or helpful deed; an instance of voluntarily assisting (someone).

faxed: Having a head of hair; hairy.

fazed: To frighten or cause hesitation; to daunt, put off (usually used in the negative); to disconcert, to perturb.

fazes: To frighten or cause hesitation; to daunt, put off (usually used in the negative); to disconcert, to perturb.

fears: A strong, uncontrollable, unpleasant emotion or feeling caused by actual or perceived danger or threat.

feast: A very large meal, often of a ceremonial nature.

feats: A relatively rare or difficult accomplishment.

feces: Digested waste material (typically solid or semi-solid) discharged from the bowels; excrement.

feels: Of or relating to the emotions.

feign: To make a false show or pretence of; to counterfeit or simulate.

feint: A movement made to confuse the opponent; a dummy.

felid: Any member of the cat family (Felidae).

fella: (chiefly South US) used to address a male

felly: The outer rim of a wheel, supported by the spokes.

felon: A person who has committed a felony.

felts: To make into felt, or a feltlike substance; to cause to adhere and mat together.

femme: A woman, a wife; a young woman or girl.

fence: A thin artificial barrier that separates two pieces of land or a house perimeter.

fends: To take care of oneself; to take responsibility for one's own well-being.

feral: A domesticated animal that has returned to the wild; an animal, particularly a domesticated animal, living independently of humans.

feria: A weekday on a Church calendar on which no feast is observed.

fermi: An obsolete unit of length equal to one femtometer or femtometre (10−15 m).

ferns: Any of a group of some twenty thousand species of vascular plants classified in the division Pteridophyta that lack seeds and reproduce by shedding spores to initiate an alternation of generations.

ferry: A ship used to transport people, smaller vehicles and goods from one port to another, usually on a regular schedule.

fesse: A horizontal band across the middle of the shield.

festa: A public holiday or feast day in Italy, Portugal, etc.

fetal: Pertaining to, or connected with, a fetus.

fetch: An act of fetching, of bringing something from a distance.

feted: (usually in the passive) To celebrate (a person).

fetes: A festival open to the public, the proceeds from which are often given to charity.

fetid: The foul-smelling asafoetida plant, or its extracts.

fetus: An unborn or unhatched vertebrate showing signs of the mature animal.

feuds: A state of long-standing mutual hostility.

feued: To bring (land) under the system of feudal tenure.

fever: A higher than normal body temperature of a person (or, generally, a mammal), usually caused by disease.

fiats: An arbitrary or authoritative command or order to do something; an effectual decree.

fiber: A single elongated piece of a given material, roughly round in cross-section, often twisted with other fibers to form thread.

fibre: A single piece of a given material, elongated and roughly round in cross-section, often twisted with other fibres to form thread.

fibro: Fibro-cement; a building material consisting of asbestos fibres and cement pressed into sheets.

fichu: A woman's lightweight triangular scarf worn over the shoulders and tied in front, or tucked into a bodice to cover the exposed part of the neck and chest.

ficus: A plant belonging to the genus Ficus, including the rubber plant.

fidos: A coin that is defective, having been incorrectly minted, often prized by collectors.

fiefs: An estate held by a person on condition of providing military service to a superior.

field: A land area free of woodland, cities, and towns; open country.

fiend: A devil or demon; a malignant or diabolical being; an evil spirit.

fifes: A small shrill pipe, resembling the piccolo flute, used chiefly to accompany the drum in military music

fifth: The person or thing in the fifth position.

fifty: A banknote or coin with a denomination of 50.

fight: To contend in physical conflict, either singly or in war, battle etc.

filch: Something which has been filched or stolen.

filed: To commit (official papers) to some office.

files: A collection of papers collated and archived together.

filet: A headband; a ribbon or other band used to tie the hair up, or keep a headdress in place, or for decoration.

fills: To occupy fully, to take up all of.

films: A thin layer of some substance; a pellicle; a membranous covering, causing opacity.

filmy: Resembling or made of a thin film; gauzy

filth: Dirt; foul matter; that which soils or defiles.

final: A final examination; a test or examination given at the end of a term or class; the test that concludes a class.

finca: A country estate, farm or ranch in Spain or Hispanic America.

finch: Any bird of the family Fringillidae, seed-eating passerine birds, native chiefly to the Northern Hemisphere and usually having a conical beak.

finds: Anything that is found (usually valuable), as objects on an archeological site or a person with talent.

fined: To make finer, purer, or cleaner; to purify or clarify.

finis: The end (of a book or other work).

finny: (of a fish) Having one or more fins.

fiord: A long, narrow, deep inlet between cliffs.

fired: To set (something, often a building) on fire.

fires: A (usually self-sustaining) chemical reaction involving the bonding of oxygen with carbon or other fuel, with the production of heat and the presence of flame or smouldering.

firms: A business partnership; the name under which it trades.

first: The person or thing in the first position.

firth: An arm or inlet of the sea; a river estuary.

fishy: A cold-blooded vertebrate animal that lives in water, moving with the help of fins and breathing with gills.

fists: A hand with the fingers clenched or curled inward.

fiver: A banknote with a value of five units of currency.

fixed: To pierce; now generally replaced by transfix.

fixer: Agent noun of fix; one who, or that which, fixes.

fjord: A long, narrow, deep inlet between cliffs.

flags: A piece of cloth, often decorated with an emblem, used as a visual signal or symbol.

flail: A tool used for threshing, consisting of a long handle with a shorter stick attached with a short piece of chain, thong or similar material.

flair: A natural or innate talent or aptitude.

flake: A loose filmy mass or a thin chiplike layer of anything

flaky: Consisting of flakes or of small, loose masses; lying, or cleaving off, in flakes or layers; flakelike.

flame: The visible part of fire; a stream of burning vapour or gas, emitting light and heat.

flank: The flesh between the last rib and the hip; the side.

flans: Baked tart with sweet or savoury filling in an open-topped pastry case. (Compare quiche.)

flash: A device that produces a short flash of light to help illuminate a scene, mostly for night-time or indoors photography.

flask: A narrow-necked vessel of metal or glass, used for various purposes; as of sheet metal, to carry gunpowder in; or of wrought iron, to contain quicksilver; or of glass, to heat water in, etc.

flays: To cause to fly; put to flight; drive off (by frightening).

fleas: To cause to fly; put to flight; drive off (by frightening).

fleet: A group of vessels or vehicles.

flesh: The soft tissue of the body, especially muscle and fat.

flews: (chiefly plural) The thick, dangling upper lip of certain breeds of dog, or the canine equivalent of the upper lip.

flick: A short, quick movement, especially a brush, sweep, or flip.

flics: A data file containing computer animations.

flied: To hit a fly ball; to hit a fly ball that is caught for an out. Compare ground (verb) and line (verb).

flier: That which flies, as a bird or insect.

flies: The open area above a stage where scenery and equipment may be hung.

fling: An act of throwing, often violently.

flips: A maneuver which rotates an object end over end.

flirt: A sudden jerk; a quick throw or cast; a darting motion

float: A buoyant device used to support something in water or another liquid.

floes: A low, flat mass of floating ice.

flood: A (usually disastrous) overflow of water from a lake or other body of water due to excessive rainfall or other input of water.

floor: The interior bottom or surface of a house or building; the supporting surface of a room.

flops: Any simple operation, such as addition, multiplication or division, performed on floating point numbers using a single operation.

flora: Plants considered as a group, especially those of a particular country, region, time, etc.

flory: (especially of a cross) Decorated (finished at the ends) with fleurs-de-lis.

floss: A thread used to clean the gaps between the teeth.

flour: Powder obtained by grinding or milling cereal grains, especially wheat, or other foodstuffs such as soybeans and potatoes, and used to bake bread, cakes, and pastry.

flout: The act by which something is flouted; violation of a law.

flubs: An error; a mistake in the performance of an action.

flues: A pipe or duct that carries gaseous combustion products away from the point of combustion (such as a furnace).

fluff: Anything light, soft or fuzzy, especially fur, hair, feathers.

fluid: Any substance which can flow with relative ease, tends to assume the shape of its container, and obeys Bernoulli's principle; a liquid, gas or plasma.

fluke: A lucky or improbable occurrence, with the implication that the occurrence could not be repeated.

flume: A ravine or gorge, usually one with water running through.

flung: To move (oneself) abruptly or violently; to rush or dash.

flunk: Of a student, to fail a class; to not pass.

flush: A group of birds that have suddenly started up from undergrowth, trees etc.

foamy: An inexpensive surfboard made of extruded polystyrene foam

focal: Belonging to, concerning, or located at a focus

fogey: A dull old fellow; a person behind the times, over-conservative, or slow.

foggy: Obscured by mist or fog; unclear; hazy

fohns: A warm dry wind blowing down the north sides of the Alps, especially in Switzerland.

foils: A very thin sheet of metal.

folia: A leaf, especially a thin leaf or plate.

folio: A leaf of a book or manuscript

folks: A grouping of smaller peoples or tribes as a nation.

folky: Having the character of folk music

fondu: The graded shift from one color into another.

fonts: A receptacle in a church for holy water, especially one used in baptism.

fools: A person with poor judgment or little intelligence.

foots: To use the foot to kick (usually a ball).

forbs: Any non-woody flowering plant that is not a graminoid (a grass, sedge, or rush).

forby: Uncommon; out of the ordinary; extraordinary; superior.

forgo: To let pass, to leave alone, to let go.

forks: A pronged tool having a long straight handle, used for digging, lifting, throwing etc.

forts: A fortified defensive structure stationed with troops.

forty: A bottle of beer containing forty fluid ounces.

fossa: A pit, groove, cavity, or depression.

fosse: A pit, groove, cavity, or depression.

fouls: A breach of the rules of a game, especially one involving inappropriate contact with an opposing player in order to gain an advantage; for example, tripping someone up in soccer, or contact of any kind in basketball.

fours: The digit or figure 4; an occurrence thereof.

fresh: A rush of water, along a river or onto the land; a flood.

frets: Agitation of the surface of a fluid by fermentation or some other cause; a rippling on the surface of water.

fries: (usually in the plural, fries) A fried strip of potato.

frill: A strip of pleated fabric or paper used as decoration or trim.

frisk: A frolic; a fit of wanton gaiety; a gambol: a little playful skip or leap.

front: The foremost side of something or the end that faces the direction it normally moves.

frore: Especially of a liquid, to become solid due to low temperature.

frost: A cover of minute ice crystals on objects that are exposed to the air. Frost is formed by the same process as dew, except that the temperature of the frosted object is below freezing.

frown: A facial expression in which the eyebrows are brought together, and the forehead is wrinkled, usually indicating displeasure, sadness or worry, or less often confusion or concentration.

frows: A cleaving tool for splitting cask staves and shingles from the block.

froze: Especially of a liquid, to become solid due to low temperature.

frugs: (usually preceded by definite article) A dance derived from the twist, popular in the 1960s.

fruit: (often in the plural) In general, a product of plant growth useful to man or animals.

frump: A frumpy person, somebody who is unattractive, drab or dowdy.

fubsy: Short and stout; low and wide

fucus: Any alga of the genus Fucus.

fudge: A type of very sweet candy or confection, usually made from sugar, butter, and milk or cream. Often used in the US synonymously with chocolate fudge.

fuels: Substance consumed to provide energy through combustion, or through chemical or nuclear reaction.

fugue: A contrapuntal piece of music wherein a particular melody is played in a number of voices, each voice introduced in turn by playing the melody.

fulls: (of the moon) To become full or wholly illuminated.

funds: A sum or source of money.

furls: To lower, roll up and secure (something, such as a sail or flag)

furry: An animal character with human-like characteristics; most commonly refers to such characters created by members of the furry subculture.

furze: A thorny evergreen shrub, with yellow flowers, Ulex gen. et spp., of which Ulex europaeus is particularly common upon the plains and hills of Great Britain and Ireland.

fused: To melt together; to blend; to mix indistinguishably.

fuses: A cord that, when lit, conveys the fire to some explosive device.

fusil: A bearing of a rhomboidal figure, originally representing a spindle in shape, longer than a heraldic lozenge.

fussy: Anxious or particular about petty details.

fuzed: (professional usage) To attach a fuze to.

fuzzy: (often in the plural) A very small piece of plush material.

gadid: Any member of the family Gadidae of fish such as cod and pollack.

gaffe: A foolish and embarrassing error, especially one made in public.

gaged: To give or deposit as a pledge or security; to pawn.

gages: Something, such as a glove or other pledge, thrown down as a challenge to combat (now usually figurative).

gaits: Manner of walking or stepping; bearing or carriage while moving.

gales: A very strong wind, more than a breeze, less than a storm; number 7 through to 9 winds on the 12-step Beaufort scale.

gamin: A homeless boy; a male street urchin; also (more generally), a cheeky, street-smart boy.

gammy: Injured, or not functioning properly (with respect to legs).

ganef: A thief; a rascal or scoundrel.

gaols: A place or institution for the confinement of persons held in lawful custody or detention, especially for minor offenses or with reference to some future judicial proceeding.

gaped: To open the mouth wide, especially involuntarily, as in a yawn, anger, or surprise.

gapes: An act of gaping; a yawn.

garbs: Fashion, style of dressing oneself up.

garth: A grassy quadrangle surrounded by cloisters

gases: Matter in a state intermediate between liquid and plasma that can be contained only if it is fully surrounded by a solid (or in a bubble of liquid) (or held together by gravitational pull); it can condense into a liquid, or can (rarely) become a solid directly.

gasps: A short, sudden intake of breath.

gassy: Having the nature of, or containing, gas.

gated: To keep something inside by means of a closed gate.

gates: A doorlike structure outside a house.

gaudy: One of the large beads in the rosary at which the paternoster is recited.

gauge: A measure; a standard of measure; an instrument to determine dimensions, distance, or capacity; a standard

gault: A type of stiff, blue clay, sometimes used for making bricks.

gaurs: An East Indian species of wild cattle (Bos gaurus), of large size and an untamable disposition.

gauss: The unit of magnetic field strength in CGS systems of units, equal to 0.0001 tesla.

gauze: A thin fabric with a loose, open weave.

gauzy: Having the qualities of gauze; light, thin, transparent, hazy.

gayal: Bos frontalis, a Southern Asiatic species of wild cattle.

gazes: A fixed look; a look of eagerness, wonder, or admiration; a continued look of attention.

gears: Equipment or paraphernalia, especially that used for an athletic endeavor.

geeks: A carnival performer specializing in bizarre and unappetizing behavior.

geese: Any of various grazing waterfowl of the family Anatidae, which have feathers and webbed feet and are capable of flying, swimming, and walking on land, and which are bigger than ducks.

gelly: An explosive mixture of nitroglycerine and nitrate absorbed onto a base of wood pulp.

gemma: A bud; an asexual reproductive structure, as found in liverworts and hydra, able to produce new individuals from a cluster of cells.

genae: The cheek; the feathered side of the under mandible of a bird.

genet: Any of several Old World nocturnal, carnivorous mammals, of the genus Genetta in the family Viverridae, most of which have a spotted coat and a long, ringed tail.

genic: Of, relating to, produced by, or being a gene

genie: A jinn, a being descended from the jann, normally invisible to the human eye, but who may also appear in animal or human form.

genii: Someone possessing extraordinary intelligence or skill; especially somebody who has demonstrated this by a creative or original work in science, music, art etc.

genip: A succulent berry with a thick rind, the fruit of plants in the genus Genipa.

genoa: A staysail that resembles a jib but extends aft beyond the mast.

genus: A rank in the classification of organisms, below family and above species; a taxon at that rank.

geode: A nodule of stone having a cavity lined with mineral or crystal matter on the inside wall.

geoid: (geodesy) The shape that the surface of the oceans of the Earth would take under the influence of the Earth's gravity and rotation alone, extending also through the continents, disregarding other factors such as winds and tides; that is, a surface of constant gravitational potential at zero elevation.

germs: The small mass of cells from which a new organism develops; a seed, bud or spore.

gesso: A mixture of plaster of Paris and glue used to prepare a surface for painting.

getup: Enthusiastic and energetic drive or ambition

geums: Any of the genus Geum of perennial herbaceous plants.

ghats: A descending path or stairway to a river; a ford or landing-place.

ghazi: A hero or champion, especially as a Muslim against non-Muslims; often used as a title.

ghees: A type of clarified butter used in South Asian cooking; usli ghee.

ghost: The spirit; the soul of man.

ghoul: (Muslim demonology) A demon said to feed on corpses.

giant: A mythical human of very great size.

gifts: Something given to another voluntarily, without charge.

gigot: A leg of lamb or mutton.

gigue: An Irish dance, derived from the jig, used in the Partita form (Baroque Period).

gilds: To cover with a thin layer of gold; to cover with gold leaf.

gilet: A sleeveless jacket similar to a waistcoat.

gills: (animal anatomy) a breathing organ of fish and other aquatic animals

gilts: Gold or other metal in a thin layer; gilding.

gimme: That which is easily obtained, or certain to occur.

ginzo: A person of Italian birth or descent.

gipsy: (sometimes offensive) A member of the Romani people, or one of the sub-groups (Roma, Sinti, Romanichal, etc).

girds: To bind with a flexible rope or cord.

licks: The act of licking; a stroke of the tongue.

lidar: The optical analogue of radar, using intense pulses of laser light to measure the composition and structure of the atmosphere.

lidos: Part of the sea by a beach sectioned off for swimming and other aquatic activities.

liege: A free and independent person; specifically, a lord paramount; a sovereign.

lifer: A prisoner sentenced to life in prison.

lifts: An act of lifting or raising.

liger: An animal born to a male lion and a tigress.

light: Visible electromagnetic radiation. The human eye can typically detect radiation (light) in the wavelength range of about 400 to 750 nanometers. Nearby shorter and longer wavelength ranges, although not visible, are commonly called ultraviolet and infrared light.

liked: To enjoy, be pleased by; favor; be in favor of.

liken: (followed by to or unto) To compare; to state that (something) is like (something else).

likes: (usually in the plural) Something that a person likes (prefers).

lilac: A large shrub of the genus Syringa, especially Syringa vulgaris, bearing white, pale-pink or purple flowers.

lilts: Animated, brisk motion; spirited rhythm; sprightliness.

limba: A large African tree, Terminalia superba, whose hard wood is used for furniture, table tennis paddles and musical instruments.

limbi: A border of an anatomical part, such as the edge of the cornea.

limbo: (Roman Catholic theology, since circa 400 A.D.) The place where innocent souls exist temporarily until they can enter heaven, notably those of the saints who died before the advent of Christ (limbus patruum) and those of unbaptized but innocent children (limbus infantum).

limbs: A major appendage of human or animal, used for locomotion (such as an arm, leg or wing).

limed: To treat with calcium hydroxide or calcium oxide (lime).

limen: A liminal point; the threshold of a physiological or psychological response.

limes: A boundary or border, especially of the Roman Empire.

limey: An Englishman or other Briton, or a person of British descent.

limit: A restriction; a bound beyond which one may not go.

limns: To draw or paint; to delineate.

limos: An automobile body with seats and permanent top like a coupe, and with the top projecting over the driver and a projecting front.

lined: To place (objects) into a line (usually used with "up"); to form into a line; to align.

linen: Thread or cloth made from flax fiber.

liner: Someone who fits a lining to something.

lines: A path through two or more points (compare ‘segment’); a continuous mark, including as made by a pen; any path, curved or straight.

linga: (Shaivism) The aniconic representation traditionally worshipped as a symbol of or in connection with Shiva.

lingo: Language, especially language peculiar to a particular group, field, or region; jargon or a dialect.

lings: Any of various marine food fish, of the genus Molva, resembling the cod.

links: Some text or a graphic in an electronic document that can be activated to display another document or trigger an action.

linns: A pool of water, especially one below a waterfall.

lions: A big cat, Panthera leo, native to Africa, India and formerly much of Europe.

lipid: Any of a group of organic compounds including the fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and triglycerides. Lipids are characterized by being insoluble in water, and account for most of the fat present in the human body.

lisle: A type of strong cotton thread, or a cloth woven from such thread.

lisps: The habit or an act of lisping.

lists: A strip of fabric, especially from the edge of a piece of cloth.

litas: The former currency or money of Lithuania, divided into 100 centai.

liter: The metric unit of fluid measure, equal to one cubic decimetre. Symbols: l, L, ℓ

litre: The metric unit of fluid measure, equal to one cubic decimetre. Symbols: l, L, ℓ

lived: To be alive; to have life.

liven: To cause to be more lively, or to become more lively.

liver: A large organ in the body that stores and metabolizes nutrients, destroys toxins and produces bile. It is responsible for thousands of biochemical reactions.

llama: A South American mammal of the camel family, Lama glama, used as a domestic beast of burden and a source of wool and meat.

llano: A plain or steppe in parts of Latin America.

loach: A bottom-feeding freshwater fish in the superfamily or suborder Cobitoidea.

loads: A burden; a weight to be carried.

loafs: To do nothing, to be idle.

loamy: Consisting of loam; partaking of the nature of loam; resembling loam.

loans: An act or instance of lending, an act or instance of granting something for temporary use.

lobar: Of or relating to a lobe.

lobby: An entryway or reception area; vestibule; passageway; corridor.

lobes: Any projection or division, especially one of a somewhat rounded form.

local: A person who lives near a given place.

locks: Something used for fastening, which can only be opened with a key or combination.

locos: A certain species of Astragalus or Oxytropis, capable of causing locoism.

locus: A place or locality, especially a centre of activity or the scene of a crime.

loden: A thick waterproof cloth used for garments.

lodes: A way or path; a road.

lodge: A building for recreational use such as a hunting lodge or a summer cabin.

loess: Any sediment, dominated by silt, of eolian (wind-blown) origin

lofts: (except in derivatives) air, the air; the sky, the heavens.

lofty: High, tall, having great height or stature

logia: A traditional saying of a religious leader.

logic: A method of human thought that involves thinking in a linear, step-by-step manner about how a problem can be solved. Logic is the basis of many principles including the scientific method.

login: A combination of a user's identification and password used to enter a computer, program, network, etc.

logos: A form of rhetoric in which the writer or speaker uses logic as the main argument.

loins: The part of the body (of humans and quadrupeds) at each side of the backbone, between the ribs and hips

lolls: To act lazily or indolently while reclining; to lean; to lie at ease.

lolly: A piece of hard candy on a stick; a lollipop.

loner: One who is alone, lacking or avoiding the company of others.

longa: (Australian Aboriginal) Belonging to; of, in, at, to.

longe: A long rope or flat web line, more commonly referred to as a longe line, approximately 20-30 feet long, attached to the bridle, longeing cavesson, or halter of a horse and used to control the animal while longeing.

loofa: A tropical vine, of the genus Luffa, having almost cylindrical fruit with a spongy, fibrous interior; the dishcloth gourd

looms: A utensil; tool; a weapon; (usually in compound) an article in general.

loony: An insane or very foolish person.

loops: A length of thread, line or rope that is doubled over to make an opening.

loots: To steal, especially as part of war, riot or other group violence.

loped: To travel an easy pace with long strides.

lopes: An easy pace with long strides.

lords: The master of the servants of a household; the master of a feudal manor

lordy: Expressing mild emotion, such as exasperation or frustration.

lores: All the facts and traditions about a particular subject that have been accumulated over time through education or experience.

loris: Any of several small, slow-moving primates, of the family Lorisidae, found in India and southeast Asia.

lorry: A motor vehicle for transporting goods, and in some cases people; a truck.

loser: A person who loses; one who fails to win or thrive.

loses: To cause (something) to cease to be in one's possession or capability due to unfortunate or unknown circumstances, events or reasons.

lossy: Of a communication channel, subject to loss of signal strength.

lotas: A spherical pot, specifically a water pot used for washing and ablution, typically made of brass.

lotic: Characterised by flowing water; swiftly flowing; concerned with flowing rivers, streams, etc.

lotto: A game of chance similar to bingo

lotus: A kind of aquatic plant, genus Nelumbo in the family Nelumbonaceae.

lough: A lake or long, narrow inlet, especially in Ireland.

louis: Any gold or silver coin issued by the French kings from Louis XIII to Louis XVI and bearing their image on the obverse side, particularly the gold louis d'ors, originally a French form of the Spanish doubloon but varying in value between 10 and 24 livres.

loupe: A magnifying glass, usually mounted in an eyepiece, often used by jewellers and watchmakers.

loups: A mass of iron in a pasty condition gathered into a ball for the tilt hammer or rolls.

louse: A small parasitic wingless insect of the order Psocodea.

lousy: Remarkably bad; of poor quality, dirty, or underhanded; mean, contemptible.

louts: A troublemaker, often violent; a rude violent person; a yob.

loved: (usually transitive, sometimes intransitive, stative) To have a strong affection for (someone or something).

lover: One who loves and cares for another person in a romantic way; a sweetheart, love, soulmate, boyfriend, girlfriend or spouse.

lovey: An informal mode of address (associated most often with actors and the like).

lower: Situated close to, or even below, the ground or another normal reference plane; not high or lofty.

lowly: Not high; not elevated in place; low.

loyal: Having or demonstrating undivided and constant support for someone or something.

luaus: An elaborate Hawaiian feast featuring traditional foods and entertainment.

lubra: (now racially offensive) A female Aboriginal Australian.

lucks: Something that happens to someone by chance, a chance occurrence, especially a favourable one.

lucky: (of people) Favoured by luck; fortunate; having good success or good fortune

lucre: Money, riches, or wealth, especially when seen as having a corrupting effect or causing greed, or obtained in an underhanded manner.

luffa: A tropical vine, of the genus Luffa, having almost cylindrical fruit with a spongy, fibrous interior; the dishcloth gourd

luffs: The vertical edge of a sail that is closest to the direction of the wind.

luger: Someone who competes in the luge.

luges: A racing sled for one or two people that is ridden with the rider or riders lying on their back.

lulls: A period of rest or soothing.

lulus: A remarkable person, object or idea.

lumen: In the International System of Units, the derived unit of luminous flux; the light that is emitted in a solid angle of one steradian from a source of one candela. Symbol: lm.

lumps: Something that protrudes, sticks out, or sticks together; a cluster or blob; a mound or mass of no particular shape.

lunar: The middle bone of the proximal series of the carpus in the wrist, which is shaped like a half-moon.

lunch: A light meal usually eaten around midday, notably when not as main meal of the day.

lunes: A fit of lunacy or madness; a period of frenzy; a crazy or unreasonable freak.

lunge: A sudden forward movement, especially with a sword.

lungi: A garment worn around the waist, especially by men, in Southern India, Bangladesh, Burma, and Pakistan.

lungs: A biological organ of vertebrates that controls breathing and oxygenates the blood.

lunks: A fool; an idiot; a lunkhead.

lupin: Any member of the genus Lupinus in the family Fabaceae.

lupus: Any of a number of autoimmune diseases, the most common of which is systemic lupus erythematosus.

lured: To attract by temptation etc.; to entice

lures: Something that tempts or attracts, especially one with a promise of reward or pleasure

lurks: To remain concealed in order to ambush.

lusts: (usually in the phrase "lust after") To look at or watch with a strong desire, especially of a sexual nature.

lusty: Exhibiting lust (in the obsolete sense meaning "vigor"); strong, healthy, robust; vigorous; full of sap or vitality.

luted: To play on a lute, or as if on a lute.

lutes: A fretted stringed instrument of European origin, similar to the guitar, having a bowl-shaped body or soundbox; any of a wide variety of chordophones with a pear-shaped body and a neck whose upper surface is in the same plane as the soundboard, with strings along the neck and parallel to the soundboard.

lyase: Any of many classes of enzyme that catalyze the breaking of a specific form of bond

lycee: A public secondary school in France.

lying: To rest in a horizontal position on a surface.

lynch: To execute (somebody) without a proper legal trial or procedure, especially by hanging and backed by a mob.

lyres: An ancient stringed musical instrument (a yoke lute chordophone) of Greek origin, consisting of two arms extending from a body to a crossbar (a yoke), and strings, parallel to the soundboard, connecting the body to the yoke.

lysed: To burst or cut a cell or cell structure; to induce lysis.

lyses: To burst or cut a cell or cell structure; to induce lysis.

lysin: Any substance or antibody that can cause the destruction (by lysis) of blood cells, bacteria etc

lysis: A gradual recovery from disease (opposed to crisis).

lytic: Of, relating to, or causing lysis

maars: A broad volcanic crater, usually filled with water to form a lake.

macaw: Any of various parrots of the genera Ara, Anodorhynchus, Cyanopsitta, Orthopsittaca, Primolius and Diopsittaca of Central and South America, including the largest parrots and characterized by long sabre-shaped tails, curved powerful bills, and usually brilliant plumage.

maced: To hit someone or something with a mace.

macer: A mace bearer; specifically, an officer of a court in Scotland.

macho: A macho person; a person who tends to display masculine characteristics, such as domineering, fierceness, and bravado.

macks: An individual skilled in the art of seduction using verbal skills.

macle: Chiastolite; so called from the tessellated appearance of a cross-section.

macro: Very large in scope or scale.

madam: A polite form of address for a woman or lady.

madly: In a mad manner; without reason or understanding; wildly.

meats: The flesh (muscle tissue) of an animal used as food.

meaty: Of, relating to, or containing meat.

mebos: A type of sweet snack food consisting of dried apricot made into a pulp and flavoured with salt and sugar.

medal: A stamped metal disc used as a personal ornament, a charm, or a religious object.

media: The middle layer of the wall of a blood vessel or lymph vessel which is composed of connective and muscular tissue.

meeds: A payment or recompense made for services rendered or in recognition of some achievement; reward, deserts; award.

meets: A sports competition, especially for track and field (a track meet) or swimming (a swim meet).

melas: A Hindu religious festival; loosely, a South Asian fair.

melba: A dessert made originally from peach (now also other fruits), ice cream, and raspberry.

melds: To combine multiple similar objects into one

melee: A battle fought at close range; hand-to-hand combat; brawling.

melic: Any of various grasses, of the genus Melica, from north temperate regions

melon: Any of various plants of the family Cucurbitaceae grown for food, generally not including the cucumber.

melts: Molten material, the product of melting.

mends: A place, as in clothing, which has been repaired by mending.

menus: The details of the food to be served at a banquet; a bill of fare.

merci: An extra card or set of cards that is allowed to play at the end of various card games.

mercy: Relenting; forbearance to cause or allow harm to another.

meres: A body of standing water, such as a lake or a pond. More specifically, it can refer to a lake that is broad in relation to its depth. Also included in place names such as Windermere.

merge: The joining together of multiple sources.

merit: A claim to commendation or a reward.

merry: Jolly and full of high spirits.

mesas: Flat area of land or plateau higher than other land, with one or more clifflike edges.

meson: (rare outside entomology) The mesial plane dividing the body into similar right and left halves.

messy: (of a place, situation, person, etc) In a disorderly state; chaotic; disorderly.

metal: (heading) Chemical elements or alloys, and the mines where their ores come from.

meter: (always meter) A device that measures things.

metic: In Ancient Greek city-states, a resident alien who did not have the rights of a citizen and who paid a tax for the right to live there.

metol: The sulphate of 4-methylaminophenol, used as a photographic developer

metre: To measure with a metering device.

mewed: To shut away, confine, lock up.

mewls: A soft cry or whimper; an act of mewling.

miasm: An unhealthy vapor or atmosphere; a miasma.

midge: Any of various small two-winged flies, for example, from the family Chironomidae or non-biting midges, the family Chaoboridae or phantom midges, and the family Ceratopogonidae or biting midges, all belonging to the order Diptera

midis: A native or inhabitant of Berlin.

midst: A place in the middle of something; may be used of a literal or metaphorical location.

miens: Demeanor; facial expression or attitude, especially one which is intended by its bearer.

might: Power, strength, force or influence held by a person or group.

miked: To microphone; to place one or more microphones (mikes) on.

milch: (of a cow, animal, etc.) Giving milk; in note

miler: (often in combination) An athlete or a horse who specializes in running races of one mile, or a specified number of miles.

miles: The international mile: a unit of length precisely equal to 1.609344 kilometers established by treaty among Anglophone nations in 1959, divided into 5,280 feet or 1,760 yards.

milia: A keratin-filled cyst that can appear just under the epidermis or on the roof of the mouth.

milks: A white liquid produced by the mammary glands of female mammals to nourish their young. From certain animals, especially cows, it is also called dairy milk and is a common food for humans as a beverage or used to produce various dairy products such as butter, cheese, and yogurt.

milky: Resembling milk in color, consistency, smell, etc.; consisting of milk.

mills: A grinding apparatus for substances such as grains, seeds, etc.

milts: The spleen, especially of an animal bred for food.

mimes: A form of acting without words; pantomime.

mimic: A person who practices mimicry, or mime.

mimsy: A nonce word in Lewis Carroll's Jabberwocky combining the senses of "flimsy" and "miserable".

miner: A person who works in a mine.

mines: Demeanor; facial expression or attitude, especially one which is intended by its bearer.

minim: A half note, drawn as a semibreve with a stem.

minks: (plural mink or minks) Any of various semi-aquatic, carnivorous mammals in the Mustelinae subfamily, similar to weasels, with dark fur, native to Europe and America, of which two species in different genera are extant: the American mink (Neovison vison) and the European mink (Mustela lutreola).

minor: A person who is below the age of majority, consent, criminal responsibility or other adult responsibilities and accountabilities.

mints: A building or institution where money (originally, only coins) is produced under government licence.

mired: To cause or permit to become stuck in mud; to plunge or fix in mud.

mirex: The pesticide and fire retardant perchloropentacyclodecane, which is a persistent organic pollutant.

mirid: Any insect of the family Miridae, a plant bug.

mirky: Hard to see through, as a fog or mist.

mirth: The emotion usually following humour and accompanied by laughter; merriment; jollity; gaiety.

miser: A person who hoards money rather than spending it; one who is cheap or extremely parsimonious.

missy: A young female, or miss; as a term of mild disparagement, typically used jokingly or rebukingly.

mists: Water or other liquid finely suspended in air.

miter: A covering for the head, worn on solemn occasions by church dignitaries, which has been made in many forms, mostly recently a tall cap with two points or peaks.

mites: Any of many minute arachnids which, along with the ticks, comprise subclass Acarina (aka Acari).

mitre: A covering for the head, worn on solemn occasions by church dignitaries, which has been made in many forms, mostly recently a tall cap with two points or peaks.

mixer: One who, or a device that, mixes or merges things together.

moans: A low, mournful cry of pain, sorrow or pleasure

moats: A deep, wide defensive ditch, normally filled with water, surrounding a fortified habitation.

mocha: A coffee drink with chocolate syrup added, or a serving thereof; a caffè mocha.

moche: An imported package of spun silk.

mocks: An imitation, usually of lesser quality.

model: A person who serves as a subject for artwork or fashion, usually in the medium of photography but also for painting or drawing.

modem: A device that encodes digital computer signals into analog/analogue telephone signals and vice versa and allows computers to communicate over a phone line.

modes: One of several ancient Greek scales.

mogul: A rich or powerful person; a magnate.

mohel: The person who performs the circumcision in a Jewish bris.

moire: Originally, a fine textile fabric made of the hair of an Asiatic goat.

molal: Of or designating a solution that contains one mole of solute per 1000g of solvent

molar: A back tooth having a broad surface used for grinding one's food.

molas: A traditional textile art form of the Kuna people of Panama and Colombia, consisting of cloth panels to be worn on clothing, featuring complex designs made with multiple layers of cloth in a reverse appliqué technique.

molds: A hollow form or matrix for shaping a fluid or plastic substance.

moles: A pigmented spot on the skin, a naevus, slightly raised, and sometimes hairy.

molls: A female companion of a gangster, especially a former or current prostitute.

molly: A woman or girl, especially of low status.

molts: The process of shedding or losing a covering of fur, feathers or skin etc.

monad: An ultimate atom, or simple, unextended point; something ultimate and indivisible.

monal: Any of three species of pheasant in the genus Lophophorus.

mondo: A dialogue between master and student designed to obtain an intuitive truth.

money: A legally or socially binding conceptual contract of entitlement to wealth, void of intrinsic value, payable for all debts and taxes, and regulated in supply.

mongo: Still-usable things salvaged (by sanmen) from garbage.

monks: A male member of a monastic order who has devoted his life for religious service.

monos: A bicycle or motorcycle trick where the front wheel is lifted off the ground while riding

monte: A game in which three or four cards are dealt face-up and players bet on which of them will first be matched in suit by others dealt.

month: A period into which a year is divided, historically based on the phases of the moon.

moods: A mental or emotional state, composure.

moody: Given to sudden or frequent changes of mind; temperamental.

mooed: Of a cow or bull, to make its characteristic lowing sound.

moons: (by extension of Moon) Any natural satellite of a planet.

moony: The act of mooning, flashing the buttocks.

moors: An extensive waste covered with patches of heath, and having a poor, light soil, but sometimes marshy, and abounding in peat; a heath

moose: The largest member of the deer family (Alces americanus, sometimes included in Alces alces), of which the male has very large, palmate antlers.

moped: To carry oneself in a depressed, lackadaisical manner; to give oneself up to low spirits; to pout, sulk.

mopes: To carry oneself in a depressed, lackadaisical manner; to give oneself up to low spirits; to pout, sulk.

moral: (of a narrative) The ethical significance or practical lesson.

moran: An unmarried Maasai or Samburu warrior.

moray: Any of the large cosmopolitan carnivorous eels of the family Muraenidae.

morel: Any of several edible mushrooms, especially the common morel or yellow morel.

mores: A set of moral norms or customs derived from generally accepted practices rather than written laws.

moron: A stupid person; an idiot; a fool.

morph: (grammar) A physical form representing some morpheme in language. It is a recurrent distinctive sound or sequence of sounds.

morse: A clasp or fastening used to fasten a cope in the front, usually decorative.

morts: Death; especially, the death of game in hunting.

mosey: To set off, get going; to start a journey.

motel: A type of hotel or lodging establishment, often located near a major highway, which typically features a series of rooms the entrances of which are immediately adjacent to a parking lot to facilitate convenient access to automobiles parked there.

motet: A composition adapted to sacred words in the elaborate polyphonic church style; an anthem.

motif: A recurring or dominant element; a theme.

motor: A machine or device that converts other energy forms into mechanical energy, or imparts motion.

motte: A raised earth mound, often topped with a wooden or stone structure and surrounded with a ditch.

motto: A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldic achievement.

mummy: An embalmed human or animal corpse wrapped in linen bandages for burial, especially as practised by the ancient Egyptians and some Native American tribes.

munch: A location or restaurant where good eating can be expected.

munge: To transform data in an undefined or unexplained manner.

mungo: A material of short fiber and inferior quality obtained by deviling woollen rags or the remnants of woollen goods, specifically those of felted, milled, or hard-spun woollen cloth, as distinguished from shoddy, or the deviled product of loose-textured woollen goods or worsted.

munia: Any of certain estrildid finches of the genera Lonchura (most instances) and Amandava (two species).

muons: An unstable elementary particle in the lepton family, having similar properties to the electron but with a mass 207 times greater.

mural: A large painting, usually drawn on a wall.

murexx: Any of the genus Murex of marine gastropods.

murid: Any rodent in the family Muridae.

murky: Hard to see through, as a fog or mist.

murre: Any seabird of the genus Uria in the family Alcidae (the auks).

mused: To become lost in thought, to ponder.

mushy: Resembling or having the consistency of mush; semiliquid, pasty, or granular.

music: A series of sounds organized in time, employing melody, harmony, tempo etc. usually to convey a mood.

musks: A greasy secretion with a powerful odour, produced in a glandular sac of the male musk deer and used in the manufacture of perfumes.

musth: A time during which male elephants exhibit increased levels of sexual activity and aggressiveness and often secrete leaking temporin from the sides of their heads.

musts: Something that is mandatory or required.

mutts: A monastic or similar religious establishment in Hinduism and Jainism, usually more formal and hierarchical than an ashram.

myall: (Australian Aboriginal) A stranger; an ignorant person.

mynah: One of the South and East Asian birds of the starling family Sturnidae.

mynas: One of the South and East Asian birds of the starling family Sturnidae.

myrrh: A red-brown resinous material, the dried sap of a tree of the species Commiphora myrrha.

mysid: Any crustacean of the family Mysidae.

myths: A traditional story which embodies a belief regarding some fact or phenomenon of experience, and in which often the forces of nature and of the soul are personified; a sacred narrative regarding a god, a hero, the origin of the world or of a people, etc.

nabob: An Indian ruler within the Mogul empire.

nacho: A single tortilla chip from a dish of nachos.

nadir: The point of the celestial sphere, directly opposite the zenith; inferior pole of the horizon; point of the celestial sphere directly under the place of observation.

naevi: A pigmented, raised or otherwise abnormal area on the skin. Naevi may be congenital or acquired, and are always benign.

naiad: A female deity (nymph) associated with water, especially a spring, stream, or other fresh water.

nails: The thin, horny plate at the ends of fingers and toes on humans and some other animals.

naira: The official currency of Nigeria, which replaced the pound in 1973; the principal denomination of the currency, equal to 100 kobo.

naker: A small drum, of Arabic origin, and the forebear of the European kettledrum.

names: Any nounal word or phrase which indicates a particular person, place, class, or thing.

nance: To move in a prissy or stereotypically gay way.

nancy: An effeminate man, especially a homosexual.

napes: The back part of the neck.

napoo: To finish; to put an end to; to kill.

nappa: Brassica rapa subsp. pekinensis, a kind of Chinese cabbage.

nappe: The profile of a body of water flowing over an obstruction in a vertical drop.

nappy: An absorbent garment worn by a baby who does not yet have voluntary control of his or her bladder and bowels or by someone who is incontinent; a diaper.

nards: Nardostachys jatamansi, a flowering plant of the valerian family that grows in the Himalayas, used as a perfume, an incense, a sedative, and an herbal medicine.

narky: Irritated, in a bad mood; disparaging.

nasal: A medicine that operates through the nose; an errhine.

nates: The two anterior of the four lobes on the dorsal side of the midbrain of most mammals; the anterior optic lobes.

naval: Of or relating to a navy.

navel: The indentation or bump remaining in the abdomen of mammals where the umbilical cord was attached before birth.

naves: The middle or body of a church, extending from the transepts to the principal entrances.

navvy: A laborer on a civil engineering project such as a canal or railroad.

nawab: A Muslim official in South Asia acting as a provincial deputy ruler under the Mughal empire; a local governor.

nazis: A member of the National Socialist German Workers Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei, commonly called the NSDAP or Nazi Party).

neaps: The tongue or pole of a cart or other vehicle drawn by two animals.

nears: The left side of a horse or of a team of horses pulling a carriage etc.

neats: An artificial intelligence researcher who believes that solutions should be elegant, clear and provably correct. Compare scruffy.

necks: The part of the body connecting the head and the trunk found in humans and some animals.

needs: Of necessity; necessarily; indispensably; used with an auxiliary verb (often must), and equivalent to "of need".

neems: Azadirachta indica, a large, mostly evergreen tree from India, whose seeds yield the insecticide azadirachtin.

negro: A black person; a person of sub-Saharan African descent.

negus: A drink of wine, lemon, sugar, nutmeg and hot water.

nenes: The Hawaiian goose, Branta sandvicensis, which was designated the state bird of Hawaii in 1957.

neons: The chemical element (symbol Ne) with an atomic number of 10. The lightest of the noble gases, it is a colourless, odorless inert gas.

neper: A non-SI unit of the attenuation (or sometimes gain) of field and power quantities such as electronic signals; the natural logarithm of a ratio, with 1 Np (a ratio of 2.718:1) being equivalent to 8.686 dB.

nests: A structure built by a bird as a place to incubate eggs and rear young.

netts: The amount remaining after expenses are deducted; profit.

neume: Any of a set of signs used in early musical notation.

neums: Any of a set of signs used in early musical notation.

never: At no time; on no occasion; in no circumstance.

nevus: Any of a number of different, usually benign, pigmented, raised or otherwise abnormal lesions of the skin.

newel: A central pillar around which a staircase spirals.

newsy: A distributor of news; a newsagent.

ngoma: A large social dancing event in parts of Africa.

ngwee: A currency of Zambia, one hundredth of a kwacha.

niece: A daughter of one’s sibling, brother-in-law, or sister-in-law; either the daughter of one's brother ("fraternal niece"), or of one's sister ("sororal niece").

nival: Abounding with snow; snowy; snow-covered (now especially in reference to plant habitats).

nixed: To make something become nothing; to reject or cancel.

nixes: To make something become nothing; to reject or cancel.

nizam: The hereditary sovereign of Hyderabad, a former state of India.

noble: An aristocrat; one of aristocratic blood.

nocks: To fit an arrow against the bowstring of a bow or crossbow. (See also notch.)

noise: Various sounds, usually unwanted or unpleasant.

noisy: Making a noise, especially a loud unpleasant sound

nomad: A member of a society or class who herd animals from pasture to pasture with no fixed home.

nomen: The name of a citizen of Ancient Rome, designating them as a member of a gens.

nomes: A prefecture or unit of regional government in Greece.

nonce: The one or single occasion; the present reason or purpose (now only in for the nonce).

nones: A light meal usually eaten around midday, notably when not as main meal of the day.

nonet: A composition for nine instruments or nine voices.

norms: That which is normal or typical.

noses: A protuberance on the face housing the nostrils, which are used to breathe or smell.

nosey: A look at something to satisfy one's curiosity.

notum: The back; the dorsal aspect of the thorax in insects.

nouns: (grammar, narrow sense) A word that can be used to refer to a person, animal, place, thing, phenomenon, substance, quality, or idea; one of the basic parts of speech in many languages, including English.

novae: Any sudden brightening of a previously inconspicuous star.

novas: Any sudden brightening of a previously inconspicuous star.

novel: Newly made, formed or evolved; having no precedent; of recent origin; new.

noway: In no manner or degree; not at all; nowise; no way.

nudie: Entertainment involving naked people, especially women.

nukes: A small corner formed by two walls; an alcove.

numbs: To cause to become numb (physically or emotionally).

numen: A divinity, especially a local or presiding god.

nylon: Originally, the DuPont company trade name for polyamide, a copolymer whose molecules consist of alternating diamine and dicarboxylic acid monomers bonded together; now generically used for this type of polymer.

nymph: (Greek, Roman) Any female nature spirit associated with water, forests, grotto, wind, etc.

oaken: Made from the wood of the oak tree. Also in metaphorical uses, suggesting robustness.

oakum: A material, consisting of tarred fibres, used to caulk or pack joints in plumbing, masonry, and wooden shipbuilding.

oases: A spring of fresh water, surrounded by a fertile region of vegetation, in a desert.

oasis: A spring of fresh water, surrounded by a fertile region of vegetation, in a desert.

oasts: A kiln for drying tobacco, malt and especially hops.

oater: (entertainment) A movie or television show about cowboy or frontier life; a western movie.

oaths: A solemn pledge or promise, appealing to a deity, a ruler, or another entity (not necessarily present) to attest to the truth of a statement or sincerity of one's desire to fulfill a contract or promise.

obeah: A form of folk magic, medicine or witchcraft originating in Africa and practised in parts of the Caribbean.

obeli: A symbol resembling a horizontal line (–), sometimes together with one or two dots (for example, ⨪ or ÷), which was used in ancient manuscripts and texts to mark a word or passage as doubtful or spurious, or redundant; an obelisk.

obese: Extremely overweight, especially: weighing more than 20% (for men) or 25% (for women) over their ideal weight determined by height and build; or, having a body mass index over 30 kg/m2.

obeys: To do as ordered by (a person, institution etc), to act according to the bidding of.

obols: A silver coin of Ancient Greece.

ocean: One of the large bodies of water separating the continents.

ocher: An earth pigment containing silica, aluminum and ferric oxide

ochre: An earth pigment containing silica, aluminum and ferric oxide

ocrea: A sheath around a plant stem forming from the stipule of a leaf and extending above the point of insertion of the leaf.

octal: The number system that uses the eight digits 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.

octet: A group or set of eight of something.

octyl: Any of very many isomeric univalent hydrocarbon radicals, C8H17, formally derived from octane by the loss of a hydrogen atom

oculi: A window or other opening that has an oval or circular shape (as of an eye).

odder: Differing from what is usual, ordinary or expected.

oddly: In a peculiar manner; strangely; unusually.

odeon: An ancient Greek or Roman building used for performances of music and poetry.

odeum: An ancient Greek or Roman building used for performances of music and poetry.

odors: Any smell, whether fragrant or offensive.

odour: Any smell, whether fragrant or offensive.

offal: The internal organs of an animal, used as animal food.

ogham: A single character in this alphabet.

ogive: The curve of a cumulative distribution function.

ogres: A type of brutish giant from folk tales that eats human flesh.

oiler: One who or that which oils.

oinks: The sound made by a pig, or an imitation thereof.

okrug: An administrative division of some Slavic states.

olden: From or relating to a previous era.

older: Of an object, concept, relationship, etc., having existed for a relatively long period of time.

oleum: A solution of sulfur trioxide in sulfuric acid.

olios: A rich, thick, Spanish stew consisting of meat and vegetables.

ollie: An aerial maneuver in which one catches air by leaping off the ground with the skateboard and into the air.

ology: Any branch of learning, especially one ending in “-logy”.

omasa: The third part of the stomach of a ruminant.

ombre: A large Mediterranean food fish Umbrina cirrosa

omens: Something which portends or is perceived to portend either a good or evil event or circumstance in the future, or which causes a foreboding; a portent or augury.

onset: An attack; an assault especially of an army.

oomph: Strength, power, passion or effectiveness; clout.

oozed: To be secreted or slowly leak.

opals: A mineral consisting, like quartz, of silica, but inferior to quartz in hardness and specific gravity, of the chemical formula SiO2·nH2O.

opens: To make something accessible or allow for passage by moving from a shut position.

opera: A theatrical work, combining drama, music, song and sometimes dance.

opine: To have or express an opinion; to state as an opinion; to suppose, consider (that).

orach: The saltbush: any of several plants, of the genus Atriplex, especially Atriplex hortensis or Atriplex patula, found in dry habitats, that have edible leaves resembling spinach.

orals: A spoken test or examination, particularly in a language class.

orate: To speak formally; to give a speech.

overs: A set of six legal balls bowled.

overt: Open and not concealed or secret.

ovoid: Something that is oval in shape.

ovolo: A classical convex moulding carved with an egg-and-dart ornament.

oxbow: A U-shaped piece of wood used as a collar for an ox, the upper parts fastened to its yoke

oxeye: Several daisy-like flowers in various genera,

oxide: A binary chemical compound of oxygen with another chemical element.

paise: A subdivision of currency, equal to one hundredth of a rupee in various Asian countries.

pales: To turn pale; to lose colour.

panes: An individual sheet of glass in a window, door, etc.

paste: A soft moist mixture, in particular:

It is usually due to a secretion of shelly substance around some irritating foreign particle. Its substance is the same as nacre, or mother-of-pearl. Round lustrous pearls are used in jewellery.

penni: A former Finnish currency unit, worth 1/100 of the markka.

penny: In the United Kingdom and Ireland, a copper coin worth 1/240 of a pound sterling or Irish pound before decimalisation. Abbreviation: d.

petit: (usually in the plural) A little schoolboy.

pewee: The common American tyrant flycatcher (of the genus Contopus).

piece: A part of a larger whole, usually in such a form that it is able to be separated from other parts.

piles: A mass of things heaped together; a heap.

pills: A small, usually round or cylindrical object designed for easy swallowing, usually containing some sort of medication.
