ripen: To grow ripe; to become mature (said of grain, fruit, flowers etc.)

riper: (of fruits, vegetables, seeds etc.) Ready for reaping or gathering; having attained perfection; mature

risen: To move, or appear to move, physically upwards relative to the ground.

rises: To move, or appear to move, physically upwards relative to the ground.

rishi: A Vedic poet and seer who composed Rigvedic hymns, who alone or with others invokes the deities with poetry of a sacred character.

risks: A possible adverse event or outcome

rites: That which complies with justice, law or reason.

rival: A competitor (person, team, company, etc.) with the same goal as another, or striving to attain the same thing. Defeating a rival may be a primary or necessary goal of a competitor.

rived: To tear apart by force; to rend; to split; to cleave.

riven: To tear apart by force; to rend; to split; to cleave.

river: A large and often winding stream which drains a land mass, carrying water down from higher areas to a lower point, oftentimes ending in another body of water, such as an ocean or in an inland sea.

rives: A place torn; a rent; a rift.

rivet: A cylindrical mechanical fastener that attaches multiple parts together by fitting through a hole and deforming the head(s) at either end.

riyal: The official currency of Qatar and Saudi Arabia.

roach: Certain members of the fish family Cyprinidae, including:

roads: A way used for travelling between places, originally one wide enough to allow foot passengers and horses to travel, now (US) usually one surfaced with asphalt or concrete and designed to accommodate many vehicles travelling in both directions. In the UK both senses are heard: a country road is the same as a country lane.

roams: To wander or travel freely and with no specific destination.

roans: An animal such as a horse that has a coat of a dark base color with individual white hairs mixed in.

roars: A long, loud, deep shout, as of rage or laughter, made with the mouth wide open.

roast: A cut of meat suited to roasting

robes: A long loose outer garment, often signifying honorary stature.

robin: Any of various passerine birds (about 100 species) of the families Muscicapidae, Turdidae and Petroicidae (formerly Eopsaltriidae), typically with a red breast.

robot: A machine built to carry out some complex task or group of tasks by physically moving, especially one which can be programmed.

rocks: An enormous mythical bird in Eastern legend.

rodeo: A gathering of cattle to be branded.

roger: (radio telecommunications) Received (used in radio communications to acknowledge that a message has been received and understood)

rogue: A scoundrel, rascal or unprincipled, deceitful, and unreliable person.

roils: To render turbid by stirring up the dregs or sediment of.

roily: (of water) muddy, cloudy (having lots of sediment)

roles: A character or part played by a performer or actor.

rolls: The act or result of rolling, or state of being rolled.

roman: One of the main three types used for the Latin alphabet (the others being italics and blackletter), in which the ascenders are mostly straight.

romps: Someone who romps; especially, a girl or young woman who indulges in boisterous play; a tomboy.

ronde: A kind of script in which the heavy strokes are nearly upright, giving the characters when taken together a round look.

rondo: A musical composition, commonly of a lively, cheerful character, in which the first strain recurs after each of the other strains.

ronin: A masterless samurai (who often becomes a mercenary to make ends meet).

roods: A crucifix, cross, especially in a church.

roofs: The external covering at the top of a building.

rooks: A European bird, Corvus frugilegus, of the crow family.

roost: The place where a bird sleeps (usually its nest or a branch).

roots: The part of a plant, generally underground, that anchors and supports the plant body, absorbs and stores water and nutrients, and in some plants is able to perform vegetative reproduction.

roper: An accomplice who locates a mark to be swindled by a confidence trickster.

ropes: Thick strings, yarn, monofilaments, metal wires, or strands of other cordage that are twisted together to form a stronger line.

ropey: Resembling rope in appearance or texture, used especially of muscles that are thick or hard to the touch.

roque: A form of croquet using short-handled mallets, and played on a hard surface

rorty: Boisterous, rowdy, saucy, dissipated, or risqué.

rosed: To make rose-coloured; to redden or flush.

roses: A shrub of the genus Rosa, with red, pink, white or yellow flowers.

rosin: A solid form of resin, obtained from liquid resin by vaporizing its volatile components.

rotas: A schedule that allocates some task, responsibility or (rarely) privilege between a set of people according to a (possibly periodic) calendar.

rotor: A rotating part of a mechanical device, for example in an electric motor, generator, alternator or pump.

rouge: Red or pink makeup to add colour to the cheeks; blusher.

rough: The unmowed part of a golf course.

round: So as to form a circle or trace a circular path, or approximation thereof.

roust: A strong tide or current, especially in a narrow channel.

route: A course or way which is traveled or passed.

routs: A noise, especially a loud one

rover: (usually in the plural) A randomly selected target.

rowed: To propel (a boat or other craft) over water using oars.

rowel: The small spiked wheel on the end of a spur.

rowen: A second crop of hay; aftermath.

royal: A royal person; a member of a royal family.

rubes: A person of rural heritage; a yokel.

ruble: The monetary unit of Russia, Belarus and Transnistria equal to 100 kopeks (Russian: копе́йка, Belarusian: капе́йка). The Russian ruble's symbol is ₽.

ruche: A strip of fabric which has been fluted or pleated.

rucks: An enormous mythical bird in Eastern legend.

ruffe: Gymnocephalus cernua, a small Eurasian freshwater fish.

ruffs: A circular frill or ruffle on a garment, especially a starched, fluted frill at the neck in Elizabethan and Jacobean England (1560s–1620s).

rugby: (usually uncountable) A form of football in which players can hold or kick an ovoid ball. The ball cannot be handled forwards and points are scored by touching the ball to the ground in the area past their opponent’s territory or kicking the ball between goalposts and over a crossbar.

ruing: To cause to repent of sin or regret some past action.

ruins: (sometimes in the plural) The remains of a destroyed or dilapidated construction, such as a house or castle.

ruled: To regulate, be in charge of, make decisions for, reign over.

ruler: A (usually rigid), flat, rectangular measuring or drawing device with graduations in units of measurement; a straightedge with markings.

rumba: A slow-paced Cuban partner dance in 4:4 time.

rumen: The first compartment of the stomach of a cow or other ruminants.

rummy: A card game with many rule variants, conceptually similar to mahjong.

rumor: A statement or claim of questionable accuracy, from no known reliable source, usually spread by word of mouth.

rumps: The hindquarters of a four-legged mammal, not including its legs

runes: A letter, or character, belonging to the written language of various ancient Germanic peoples, especially the Scandinavians and the Anglo-Saxons.

rungs: A crosspiece forming a step of a ladder; a round.

runts: The smallest animal of a litter.

rupee: The common name for the monetary currencies used in modern India, Mauritius, Nepal, Pakistan, the Seychelles, or Sri Lanka, often abbreviated ₨.

rural: A person from the countryside; a rustic.

ruses: A turning or doubling back, especially of animals to get out of the way of hunting dogs.

rusts: The deteriorated state of iron or steel as a result of moisture and oxidation.

rutin: A flavonoid, found in many plants, that is a glycoside of quercetin and rutinose.

ryots: A farmer or tiller of the soil.

saber: A light sword, sharp along the front edge, part of the back edge, and at the point.

sable: A small carnivorous mammal of the Old World that resembles a weasel, Martes zibellina, from cold regions in Eurasia and the North Pacific islands, valued for its dark brown fur (Wikipedia).

sabre: A light sword, sharp along the front edge, part of the back edge, and at the point.

sacks: A bag or pouch inside a plant or animal that typically contains a fluid.

sadhu: An ascetic or practitioner of yoga (yogi) who has given up pursuit of the first three Hindu goals of life: kama (enjoyment), artha (practical objectives) and even dharma (duty).

safer: Not in danger; out of harm's reach.

safes: A box, usually made of metal, in which valuables can be locked for safekeeping.

sagas: An Old Norse (Icelandic) prose narrative, especially one dealing with family or social histories and legends.

sages: A wise person or spiritual teacher; someone of gravity and wisdom, especially, a teacher venerable for years, and of sound judgment and prudence; a grave or stoic philosopher.

sagos: A powdered starch obtained from certain palms used as a food thickener.

sahib: A term of respect for a white European or other person of rank in colonial India.

saiga: Saiga tatarica, an antelope which inhabits a vast area between Kalmykia, Kazakhstan, southern Siberia.

sails: A piece of fabric attached to a boat and arranged such that it causes the wind to drive the boat along. The sail may be attached to the boat via a combination of mast, spars and ropes.

saint: A person whom a church or another religious group has officially recognised as especially holy or godly; one eminent for piety and virtue.

saker: A falcon (Falco cherrug) native of Southern Europe and Asia.

sakes: An alcoholic beverage made from fermenting various forms of rice, usually with an ABV similar to wine.

sakis: An alcoholic beverage made from fermenting various forms of rice, usually with an ABV similar to wine.

salad: A food made primarily of a mixture of raw or cold ingredients, typically vegetables, usually served with a dressing such as vinegar or mayonnaise.

salal: A leathery-leaved North American shrub, Gaultheria shallon, with edible sepals and leaves.

salat: The obligatory prayer that Muslims are called to perform five times a day.

salep: A starch or jelly made out of plants in the Orchidaceae family, such as the early-purple orchid (Orchis mascula).

salmi: A rich stew or ragout, especially of game.

salon: A large room, especially one used to receive and entertain guests.

salps: Any of the free-swimming tunicates of the order Salpida and its single family Salpidae.

salsa: A spicy tomato sauce, often including onions and hot peppers.

salts: A common substance, chemically consisting mainly of sodium chloride (NaCl), used extensively as a condiment and preservative.

salve: An ointment, cream, or balm with soothing, healing, or calming effects.

salvo: An exception; a reservation; an excuse.

saman: A fine; a monetary penalty imposed for breaking the law.

samba: A Brazilian ballroom dance or dance style.

sands: Rock that is ground more finely than gravel, but is not as fine as silt (more formally, see grain sizes chart), forming beaches and deserts and also used in construction.

saner: Being in a healthy condition; not deranged; thinking rationally.

sappy: Excessively sweet, emotional, nostalgic; cheesy; mushy. (British equivalent: soppy)

saran: A plastic resin used to make packaging films.

sards: A variety of carnelian, of a rich reddish yellow or brownish red color.

saree: The traditional dress of women in the Indian Subcontinent; an outer garment consisting of a single length of cotton or silk, most often with one end wrapped around the waist to form a skirt, the other draped over the shoulder or head.

sarin: The neurotoxin O-isopropyl methylphosphonofluoridate, used as a chemical weapon.

saris: The traditional dress of women in the Indian Subcontinent; an outer garment consisting of a single length of cotton or silk, most often with one end wrapped around the waist to form a skirt, the other draped over the shoulder or head.

sarod: A fretless string instrument used mainly in Indian classical music.

saros: (history, Babylon) A quantity of 3600, such as a period of 3600 years.

sassy: Bold and spirited, cheeky, impudent, saucy.

satai: A dish made from small pieces of meat or fish grilled on a skewer and served with a spicy peanut sauce, originating from Indonesia and Malaysia.

sated: To satisfy the appetite or desire of; to fill up.

satin: A cloth woven from silk, nylon or polyester with a glossy surface and a dull back. (The same weaving technique applied to cotton produces cloth termed sateen).

satyr: A woodland creature with pointed ears, legs, and short horns of a goat and a fondness for unrestrained revelry.

sauce: A liquid (often thickened) condiment or accompaniment to food.

saucy: Similar to sauce; having the consistency or texture of sauce.

sauna: A room or a house designed for heat sessions.

saury: A marine epipelagic fish of the family Scomberesocidae, with beaklike jaws and a row of small finlets behind the dorsal and anal fins.

saute: To cook (food) using a small amount of fat in an open pan over a relatively high heat, allowing the food to brown and form a crust stopping it from sticking to the pan as it cooks.

saves: In various sports, a block that prevents an opponent from scoring.

savin: The evergreen shrub Juniperus sabina, endemic to Europe, which yields a medicinal oil.

savor: The specific taste or smell of something.

scabs: An incrustation over a sore, wound, vesicle, or pustule, formed during healing.

scads: Any of several fish, of the family Carangidae, from the western Atlantic.

scald: A burn, or injury to the skin or flesh, by hot liquid or steam.

scale: A ladder; a series of steps; a means of ascending.

scalp: The top of the head; the skull.

scamp: A rascal, swindler, or rogue; a ne'er-do-well.

scape: A leafless stalk growing directly out of a root.

scarf: A long, often knitted, garment worn around the neck.

scarp: The steep artificial slope below a fort's parapet

scars: A permanent mark on the skin, sometimes caused by the healing of a wound.

scary: Causing or able to cause fright.

scaup: The top of the head; the skull.

scend: The rising motion of water as a wave passes; a surge; the upward angular displacement of a vessel, opposed to pitch, the correlative downward movement.

scene: The location of an event that attracts attention.

schwa: An indeterminate central vowel sound as the "a" in "about", represented as /ə/ in IPA.

scion: A descendant, especially a first-generation descendant of a distinguished family.

scoff: Derision; ridicule; a derisive or mocking expression of scorn, contempt, or reproach.

scone: A small, rich, pastry or quick bread, sometimes baked on a griddle.

scoop: Any cup- or bowl-shaped tool, usually with a handle, used to lift and move loose or soft solid material.

scopa: Any of various body parts of non-parasitic bees that serve to carry pollen. In parasitic Hymenoptera it refers to a local patch of hairs, regardless of function.

scope: The breadth, depth or reach of a subject; a domain.

score: The total number of goals, points, runs, etc. earned by a participant in a game.

scots: A local tax, paid originally to the lord or ruler and later to a sheriff.

scour: The removal of sediment caused by swiftly moving water.

scout: A person sent out to gain and bring in tidings; especially, one employed in war to gain information about the enemy and ground.

scowl: The wrinkling of the brows or face in frowning; the expression of displeasure, sullenness, or discontent in the countenance; an angry frown.

scows: A large flat-bottomed boat, having broad, square ends.

scrag: A thin or scrawny person or animal.

scram: Leave in a hurry, go away.

scran: Food, especially that of an inferior quality; grub.

scrap: A (small) piece; a fragment; a detached, incomplete portion.

scree: Loose stony debris on a slope.

screw: A device that has a helical function.

scrim: A kind of light cotton or linen fabric, often woven in openwork patterns, -- used for curtains, etc,.

scrip: A small medieval bag used to carry food, money, utensils etc.

scrod: (sometimes New York) Any cod, pollock, haddock, or other whitefish.

scrub: One who labors hard and lives meanly; a mean fellow.

scrum: A tightly-packed and disorderly crowd of people.

scuba: (underwater diving) An apparatus carried by a diver, which includes a tank holding compressed, filtered air and a regulator which delivers the air to the diver at ambient pressure which can be used underwater.

scudi: A silver coin and unit of currency of various Italian states from the 16th to the 19th centuries.

scudo: A silver coin and unit of currency of various Italian states from the 16th to the 19th centuries.

scuff: (sometimes attributive) A mark left by scuffing or scraping.

scull: A single oar mounted at the stern of a boat and moved from side to side to propel the boat forward.

sculp: (sometimes humorous) To sculpture; to carve or engrave.

scums: A layer of impurities that accumulates at the surface of a liquid (especially molten metal or water).

scute: A horny, chitinous, or bony external plate or scale, as on the shell of a turtle or the skin of crocodiles.

scuts: A hare; a hare as the game in a hunt.

seals: A pinniped (Pinnipedia), particularly an earless seal (true seal) or eared seal.

seams: A folded-back and stitched piece of fabric; especially, the stitching that joins two or more pieces of fabric.

sears: To char, scorch, or burn the surface of (something) with a hot instrument.

sebum: A thick oily substance, secreted by the sebaceous glands of the skin, that consists of fat, keratin and cellular debris.

secco: A work painted on dry plaster, as distinguished from a fresco.

sects: An offshoot of a larger religion; a group sharing particular (often unorthodox) political and/or religious beliefs.

sedan: An enclosed windowed chair suitable for a single occupant, carried by at least two porters, in equal numbers in front and behind, using wooden rails that passed through metal brackets on the sides of the chair.

seder: The ceremonial meal held on the first night or two nights of Passover.

sedge: Any plant of the genus Carex, the true sedge, perennial, endogenous herbs, often growing in dense tufts in marshy places. They have triangular jointless stems, a spiked inflorescence, and long grasslike leaves which are usually rough on the margins and midrib. There are several hundred species.

sedum: Any of various succulent plants, of the genus Sedum, native to temperate zones; the stonecrop

seeds: A fertilized and ripened ovule, containing an embryonic plant.

seeks: To try to find; to look for; to search for.

seels: To sew together the eyes of a young hawk.

seems: To appear; to look outwardly; to be perceived as.

seeps: A small spring, pool, or other spot where liquid from the ground (e.g. water, petroleum or tar) has oozed to the surface; a place of seeping.

seers: One who sees something; an eyewitness.

segos: A perennial bulb lily found in Western North America, the Calochortus nuttallii, which has trumpet-shaped flowers.

segue: An instance of segueing, a transition.

seine: A long net having floats attached at the top and sinkers (weights) at the bottom, used in shallow water for catching fish.

seise: To vest ownership of a freehold estate in (someone).

seize: To deliberately take hold of; to grab or capture.

selah: A pause or rest of a contemplative nature.

selfs: One individual's personality, character, demeanor, or disposition.

selva: Heavily forested ground in the Amazon basin.

semee: Sprinkled, sown, strewn: said of a field or charge when strewn with small (identical) charges.

semen: A sticky, milky fluid produced in male reproductive organs that contains the reproductive cells.

semes: A folded-back and stitched piece of fabric; especially, the stitching that joins two or more pieces of fabric.

sends: To make something (such as an object or message) go from one place to another.

senna: Any of several plants of the tribe Cassieae, especially those of the genera Cassia and Senna, whose leaves and pods are used as a purgative and laxative.

senor: A Spanish term of address equivalent to sir or Mr., used alone or capitalized and prefixed to the name of a married or an older man.

sense: Any of the manners by which living beings perceive the physical world: for humans sight, smell, hearing, touch, taste.

sepal: One of the component parts of the calyx, particularly when the sepals in a plant's calyx are not fused into a single structure.

sepia: A dark brown pigment made from the secretions of the cuttlefish.

sepoy: A native soldier of the East Indies, employed in the service of a European colonial power, notably the British India army (first under the British-chartered East India Company, later in the crown colony), but also France and Portugal.

septa: A wall separating two cavities; a partition

septs: A clan, tribe, or family, proceeding from a common progenitor (used especially of the ancient clans in Ireland).

serac: Often sérac: a hard, cone-shaped, pale green, strongly flavoured cheese from Switzerland made from skimmed cowmilk and blue fenugreek (Trigonella caerulea); Schabziger, Sapsago. It is usually eaten grated, mixed with butter, or in a fondue.

serai: (In Turkish or Muslim Asian contexts) A palace.

seres: A natural succession of animal or plant communities in an ecosystem, especially a series of communities succeeding one another from the time a habitat is unoccupied to the point when a climax community is achieved.

serfs: A partially free peasant of a low hereditary class, attached like a slave to the land owned by a feudal lord and required to perform labour, enjoying minimal legal or customary rights

serif: A short line added to the end of a stroke in traditional typefaces, such as Times New Roman.

serin: Any of various small finches in the genus Serinus, with largely yellow plumage.

serow: Any of several species of Asian ungulates of the genus Capricornis.

serum: The clear yellowish liquid obtained upon separating whole blood into its solid and liquid components after it has been allowed to clot.

serve: An act of putting the ball or shuttlecock in play in various games.

seton: A few silk threads or horsehairs, or a strip of linen etc., introduced beneath the skin by a knife or needle, so as to induce suppuration; also, the issue so formed.

setup: Equipment designed for a particular purpose; an apparatus.

seven: The digit/figure 7 or an occurrence thereof.

sewed: To use a needle to pass thread repeatedly through (pieces of fabric) in order to join them together.

sewen: To use a needle to pass thread repeatedly through (pieces of fabric) in order to join them together.

sewer: A pipe or system of pipes used to remove human waste and to provide drainage.

sexed: To determine the sex of an animal.

sexes: An offshoot of a larger religion; a group sharing particular (often unorthodox) political and/or religious beliefs.

sexts: Noon, reckoned as the sixth hour of daylight.

shack: A crude, roughly built hut or cabin.

shade: Darkness where light, particularly sunlight, is blocked.

shads: Any one of several species of food fishes that make up the genus Alosa in the family Clupeidae, to which the herrings also belong; river herring.

shaft: The entire body of a long weapon, such as an arrow.

shags: Matted material; rough massed hair, fibres etc.

shahs: A king of Persia or Iran.

shaka: A greeting gesture in which the thumb and little finger are extended while curling the three middle fingers in a semi-fist. Used to express a variety of positive meanings including "all right", "hello" and "goodbye".

shake: The act of shaking or being shaken; tremulous or back-and-forth motion.

shako: A stiff, cylindrical military dress hat with a metal plate in front, a short visor, and a plume.

shale: A shell or husk; a cod or pod.

shall: (modal, auxiliary verb, defective) Used before a verb to indicate the simple future tense in the first person singular or plural.

shalt: (modal, auxiliary verb, defective) Used before a verb to indicate the simple future tense in the first person singular or plural.

shama: Copsychus malabaricus (white-rumped shama), a saxicoline songbird of India, glossy black with a white rump and brown underparts, and six other species in genus Copsychus.

shame: Uncomfortable or painful feeling due to recognition or consciousness of one's own impropriety or dishonor or something being exposed that should have been kept private.

shams: A fake; an imitation that purports to be genuine.

shank: The part of the leg between the knee and the ankle.

shape: The status or condition of something

shard: A piece of broken glass or pottery, especially one found in an archaeological dig.

share: A portion of something, especially a portion given or allotted to someone.

shark: A scaleless, predatory fish of the superorder Selachimorpha, with a cartilaginous skeleton and 5 to 7 gill slits on each side of its head.

sharp: The symbol ♯, placed after the name of a note in the key signature or before a note on the staff to indicate that the note is to be played a semitone higher.

shave: To make bald or shorter by using a tool such as a razor or pair of electric clippers to cut the hair close to the skin.

shawl: A square or rectangular piece of cloth worn as a covering for the head, neck, and shoulders, typically by women.

shawm: A mediaeval double-reed wind instrument with a conical wooden body.

shaws: A thicket; a small wood or grove.

sheaf: A quantity of the stalks and ears of wheat, rye, or other grain, bound together; a bundle of grain or straw.

shear: A cutting tool similar to scissors, but often larger.

sheep: A woolly ruminant of the genus Ovis.

sheet: A thin bed cloth used as a covering for a mattress or as a layer over the sleeper.

sheik: The leader of an Arab village, family or small tribe.

shelf: A flat, rigid structure, fixed at right angles to a wall or forming a part of a cabinet, desk etc., and used to support, store or display objects.

shell: A hard external covering of an animal.

sheng: A Chinese wind instrument, a free-reed mouth organ consisting of 13 or more bamboo pipes of various lengths, which are fixed at their bases in a wind chest made from a dried gourd (or, more recently, wood or chrome-plated brass).

sherd: A piece of broken glass or pottery, especially one found in an archaeological dig.

sheva: A Hebrew nikud vowel sign written as two vertical dots beneath a letter, indicating either the phoneme /ə/ or the complete absence of a vowel.

shews: A play, dance, or other entertainment.

shied: To avoid due to timidness or caution.

shift: A modifier key whose main function is shifting between two or more functions of any of certain other keys (usually by pressing Shift and the other button simultaneously).

shill: A person paid to endorse a product favourably, while pretending to be impartial.

shine: Brightness from a source of light.

shins: The front part of the leg below the knee; the front edge of the shin bone: Shinbone

ships: A water-borne vessel generally larger than a boat.

shire: Physical area administered by a sheriff.

shirk: One who shirks, who avoids a duty or responsibility.

shirt: An article of clothing that is worn on the upper part of the body, and often has sleeves, either long or short, that cover the arms.

shits: A gastrointestinal disorder characterized by frequent and very fluid or watery bowel movements.

shiva: A weeklong period of formal mourning for a close relative.

shivs: A knife, especially a makeshift one fashioned from something not normally used as a weapon (like a plastic spoon or a toothbrush).

shoal: A sandbank or sandbar creating a shallow.

shoes: A protective covering for the foot, with a bottom part composed of thick leather or plastic sole and often a thicker heel, and a softer upper part made of leather or synthetic material. Shoes generally do not extend above the ankle, as opposed to boots, which do.

shoji: A door or partition consisting of a wooden frame covered in rice paper.

shojo: A style of anime and manga intended for young women.

shook: A set of pieces for making a cask or box, usually wood.

shoos: To induce someone or something to leave.

shoot: The emerging stem and embryonic leaves of a new plant.

shops: An establishment that sells goods or services to the public; originally only a physical location, but now a virtual establishment as well.

shore: Land adjoining a non-flowing body of water, such as an ocean, lake or pond.

shorn: To cut, originally with a sword or other bladed weapon, now usually with shears, or as if using shears.

shots: The result of launching a projectile or bullet.

shout: A loud burst of voice or voices; a violent and sudden outcry, especially that of a multitude expressing joy, triumph, exultation, anger, or animated courage.

shown: To display, to have somebody see (something).

shows: A play, dance, or other entertainment.

showy: (sometimes derogatory) calling attention; flashy; standing out to the eye

shoyu: A dark form of soy sauce

shred: A long, narrow piece cut or torn off; a strip.

shrew: Any of numerous small, mouselike, chiefly nocturnal, mammals of the family Soricidae (order Soricomorpha).

shrub: A woody plant smaller than a tree, and usually with several stems from the same base.

shrug: A lifting of the shoulders to signal indifference or a casual lack of knowledge.

shuck: The shell or husk, especially of grains (e.g. corn/maize) or nuts (e.g. walnuts).

shunt: An act of moving (suddenly), as due to a push or shove.

shush: To be quiet; to keep quiet.

shuts: The act or time of shutting; close.

sibyl: A pagan female oracle or prophetess, especially the Cumaean sibyl.

sices: A groom, or servant with responsibility for the horses.

sicks: To incite an attack by, especially a dog or dogs.

sided: To ally oneself, be in an alliance, usually with "with" or rarely "in with"

sides: A bounding straight edge of a two-dimensional shape.

sidhe: A supernatural creature of Irish and Scottish folklore, living in Sidhe; a fairy.

sieve: A device with a mesh bottom to separate, in a granular material, larger particles from smaller ones, or to separate solid objects from a liquid.

sighs: A deep, prolonged audible inhale and exhale of breath; as when fatigued, frustrated, grieved, or relieved; the act of sighing.

sight: (in the singular) The ability to see.

sigla: A letter or other symbol that stands for a word or name.

sigma: The eighteenth letter of the Classical and Modern Greek alphabets, the twentieth letter of Old and Ancient.

signs: (sometimes also used uncountably) A visible indication.

sikes: A gutter or ditch; a small stream that frequently dries up in the summer.

silks: A fine fiber excreted by the silkworm or other arthropod (such as a spider).

silky: A seal which can magically transform into a human by shedding its skin.

sills: (also window sill) A horizontal slat which forms the base of a window.

silos: A vertical building, usually cylindrical, used for the production of silage.

silts: To clog or fill with silt.

simps: A simple person lacking common sense; a fool or simpleton.

simul: A simultaneous exhibition: one player, typically very strong, plays several games at the same time against different opponents, typically weaker.

since: From a specified time in the past.

sines: In a right triangle, the ratio of the length of the side opposite an angle to the length of the hypotenuse.

sinew: A cord or tendon of the body.

singe: A burning of the surface; a slight burn.

sings: A gathering at which people sing songs.

sinks: A basin used for holding water for washing.

sinus: A pouch or cavity in any organ or tissue, especially the paranasal sinus.

sipes: Slit in a tire to drain away surface water and improve traction.

sired: (of a male) to procreate; to father, beget, impregnate.

siree: (used as an intensifier, emphatically, after yes or no) Sir.

siren: One of a group of nymphs who lured mariners to their death on the rocks.

sires: A lord, master, or other person in authority, most commonly used vocatively: formerly in speaking to elders and superiors, later only when addressing a sovereign.

sirup: Any thick liquid that has a high sugar content and which is added to or poured over food as a flavouring.

sisal: A Central American plant, Agave sisalana, cultivated for its sword-shaped leaves that yield fibers used for rope.

sitar: A Hindustani/Indian classical stringed instrument, typically having a gourd as its resonating chamber.

sited: To situate or place a building.

situs: The position, especially the usual, normal position, of a body part or part of a plant.

sixer: A Cub Scout who leads a group of six.

sixte: The sixth defensive position, with the sword hand held at chest height, and the tip of the sword at eye level.

sixth: (not used in the plural) The person or thing in the sixth position.

sixty: The cardinal number occurring after fifty-nine and before sixty-one, represented in Roman numerals as LX and in Arabic numerals as 60.

sizar: At certain universities, e.g. Cambridge and Dublin, a student who receives an allowance for his college expenses (a study grant), originally in return for serving other (paying) students.

sized: To adjust the size of; to make a certain size.

skald: A Nordic poet of the Viking Age

skate: A light boot, fitted with a blade, used for ice skating.

skean: A quantity of yarn, thread, or the like, put up together, after it is taken from the reel. A skein of cotton yarn is formed by eighty turns of the thread around a fifty-four inch reel.

skeet: A form of trapshooting using clay targets to simulate birds in flight.

skegs: A fin-like structure to the rear of the keel of a vessel that supports the rudder and protects a propeller.

skein: A quantity of yarn, thread, or the like, put up together, after it is taken from the reel. A skein of cotton yarn is formed by eighty turns of the thread around a fifty-four inch reel.

skell: A homeless person, especially one who sleeps in the New York subway.

skene: An element of ancient Greek theater: the structure at the back of the stage.

skews: Something that has an oblique or slanted position.

skids: An out-of-control sliding motion as would result from applying the brakes too hard in a car.

skies: The atmosphere above a given point, especially as visible from the ground during the day.

skiff: Term used in tea gardens and denotes the act of cutting/pruning the bushes as per the specific norms. Various types of skiff are used viz Light Skiff (LS), Medium Skiff (MS), Deep Skiff (DS) and Level Of Skiff (LOS).

skill: Capacity to do something well; technique, ability. Skills are usually acquired or learned, as opposed to abilities, which are often thought of as innate.

skimp: To mock, deride, scorn, scold, make fun of.

skims: To pass lightly; to glide along in an even, smooth course; to glide along near the surface.

skins: The outer protective layer of the body of any animal, including of a human.

skips: A leaping, jumping or skipping movement.

skirl: A shrill sound, as of bagpipes.

skirt: An article of clothing, usually worn by women and girls, that hangs from the waist and covers the lower part of the body.

skite: A sudden hit or blow; a glancing blow.

skive: Something very easy, where one can slack off without penalty.

skuas: Any of various predatory seabirds of the family Stercorariidae that often chase other seabirds to steal their catches.

skull: The main bones of the head considered as a unit; including the cranium, facial bones, and mandible.

skunk: Any of various small mammals, of the family Mephitidae, native to North and Central America, having a glossy black with a white coat and two musk glands at the base of the tail for emitting a noxious smell as a defensive measure.

slabs: A large, flat piece of solid material; a solid object that is large and flat.

slack: The part of anything that hangs loose, having no strain upon it.

slade: A valley, a flat grassy area, a glade.

slags: Waste material from a coal mine

slams: To shut with sudden force so as to produce a shock and noise.

slang: Language outside of conventional usage and in the informal register.

slaps: A blow, especially one given with the open hand, or with something broad and flat.

slash: A slashing action or motion, particularly:

slate: A fine-grained homogeneous sedimentary rock composed of clay or volcanic ash which has been metamorphosed so that it cleaves easily into thin layers.

slats: A thin, narrow strip or bar of wood (lath) or metal.

slave: A person who is held in servitude as the property of another person, and whose labor (and often also whose body and life) is subject to the owner's volition and control.

sleds: A small, light vehicle with runners, used recreationally, mostly by children, for sliding down snow-covered hills. (A "sled" in this sense is not pulled by an animal as a "sleigh" is.)

sleep: To rest in a state of reduced consciousness.

sleet: Pellets of ice made of mostly frozen raindrops or refrozen melted snowflakes.

slept: To rest in a state of reduced consciousness.

slews: To rotate or turn something about its axis.

slice: That which is thin and broad.

slick: A covering of liquid, particularly oil.

slide: An item of play equipment that children can climb up and then slide down again.

slime: Soft, moist earth or clay, having an adhesive quality; viscous mud; any substance of a dirty nature, that is moist, soft, and adhesive; bitumen; mud containing metallic ore, obtained in the preparatory dressing.

slims: A type of cigarette substantially longer and thinner than normal cigarettes.

sling: An instrument for throwing stones or other missiles, consisting of a short strap with two strings fastened to its ends, or with a string fastened to one end and a light stick to the other.

slips: A thin, slippery mix of clay and water.

slits: A narrow cut or opening; a slot.

sloes: The small, bitter, wild fruit of the blackthorn (Prunus spinosa).

slogs: A long, tedious walk, or session of work.

sloka: A distich of Sanskrit verse, in which each line contains sixteen syllables.

sloop: A single-masted sailboat with only one headsail.

slope: An area of ground that tends evenly upward or downward.

slops: A loose outer garment; a jacket or overall.

slosh: A quantity of a liquid; more than a splash.

sloth: Laziness; slowness in the mindset; disinclination to action or labour.

slots: A broad, flat, wooden bar, a slat, especially as used to secure a door, window, etc.

slows: To make (something) run, move, etc. less quickly; to reduce the speed of.

slubs: A small thickened portion or knot found on linen yarn, caused by defects.

slues: The act of sluing or the place to which something has slued.

slugs: Any of many terrestrial pulmonate gastropod mollusks, having no (or only a rudimentary) shell.

slump: A heavy or helpless collapse; a slouching or drooping posture; a period of poor activity or performance, especially an extended period.

slums: A dilapidated neighborhood where many people live in a state of poverty.

slung: To throw with a circular or arcing motion.

slurp: A loud sucking noise made in eating or drinking

sluts: A sexually promiscuous woman or girl.

slype: A covered passageway, especially one connecting the transept of a cathedral or monastery to the chapter house.

smack: A distinct flavor, especially if slight.

small: Any part of something that is smaller or slimmer than the rest, now usually with anatomical reference to the back.

smalt: A deep blue pigment made from powdered glass mixed with cobalt oxide

smash: The sound of a violent impact; a violent striking together.

smell: A sensation, pleasant or unpleasant, detected by inhaling air (or, the case of water-breathing animals, water) carrying airborne molecules of a substance.

smelt: Any small anadromous fish of the family Osmeridae, found in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and in lakes in North America and northern part of Europe.

smews: A small compact diving duck, Mergus albellus, that breeds in the northern taiga of Europe and Asia and winters on sheltered coasts or inland lakes.

smile: A facial expression comprised by flexing the muscles of both ends of one's mouth, often showing the front teeth, without vocalisation, and in humans is a common involuntary or voluntary expression of happiness, pleasure, amusement or anxiety.

smirk: An uneven, often crooked smile that is insolent, self-satisfied or scornful

smith: A craftsperson who works metal into desired forms using a hammer and other tools, sometimes heating the metal to make it more workable, especially a blacksmith.

smock: A type of undergarment worn by women; a shift or slip.

smogs: A noxious mixture of particulates and gases that is the result of urban air pollution.

smoke: The visible vapor/vapour, gases, and fine particles given off by burning or smoldering material.

smoko: A cigarette break from work or military duty; a brief cessation of work to have a smoke, or (more generally) to take a small rest, snack etc.

snags: A stump or base of a branch that has been lopped off; a short branch, or a sharp or rough branch.

snail: Any of very many animals (either hermaphroditic or nonhermaphroditic), of the class Gastropoda, having a coiled shell.

snake: A legless reptile of the sub-order Serpentes with a long, thin body and a fork-shaped tongue.

snaps: A quick breaking or cracking sound or the action of producing such a sound.

snare: A trap (especially one made from a loop of wire, string, or leather).

snarl: A knot or complication of hair, thread, or the like, difficult to disentangle.

sneak: One who sneaks; one who moves stealthily to acquire an item or information.

sneer: A facial expression where one slightly raises one corner of the upper lip, generally indicating scorn.

snell: Quick, smart; sharp, active, brisk or nimble; lively.

snibs: A latch or fastening for a door, window etc.

snick: A small deflection of the ball off the side of the bat; often carries to the wicketkeeper for a catch

snide: An underhanded, tricky person given to sharp practise; a sharper; a cheat.

snips: The act of snipping; cutting a small amount off of something.

snits: A temper; a lack of patience; a bad mood.

snobs: A person who wishes to be seen as a member of the upper classes and who looks down on those perceived to have inferior or unrefined tastes.

snoek: An edible fish, Thyrsites atun, native to South African (Cape), South American and Australian waters, often smoked or salted.

snood: A band or ribbon for keeping the hair in place, including the hair-band formerly worn in Scotland and northern England by young unmarried women.

snook: A freshwater and marine fish of the family Centropomidae in the order Perciformes.

snool: An abject, cowardly person who submits tamely to others.

snoot: An elitist individual; one who looks down upon lower social classes.

snore: The act of snoring, and the noise produced.

snort: The sound made by exhaling or inhaling roughly through the nose.

snots: Mucus, especially mucus from the nose.

snout: The long, projecting nose, mouth, and jaw of a beast, as of pigs.

snows: The frozen, crystalline state of water that falls as precipitation.

snowy: Marked by snow, characterized by snow.

snuck: To creep or go stealthily; to come or go while trying to avoid detection, as a person who does not wish to be seen.

snuff: Finely ground or pulverized tobacco intended for use by being sniffed or snorted into the nose.

snugs: A small, comfortable back room in a pub.

soaps: A substance able to mix with both oil and water, used for cleaning, often in the form of a solid bar or in liquid form, derived from fats or made synthetically.

sober: (often with up) To make or become sober.

socks: A knitted or woven covering for the foot.

socle: A low plinth or pedestal used to display a statue or other artwork.

sodic: Of, relating to, or containing sodium.

sofar: A system for determining the position of vessels lost at sea by means of explosive sounds.

sofas: A raised area of a building's floor, usually covered with carpeting, used for sitting.

softa: A religious student, especially in Turkey

soggy: Soaked with moisture or other liquid.

soils: A mixture of mineral particles and organic material, used to support plant growth.

sokes: Any of several medieval rights, either to hold a court, or to receive fines.

solar: Of or pertaining to the sun; proceeding from the sun

soldi: An Italian coin, formerly one-twentieth of a lira.

soldo: An Italian coin, formerly one-twentieth of a lira.

soled: To pull by the ears; to pull about; haul; lug.

soles: A wooden band or yoke put around the neck of an ox or cow in the stall.

solid: A substance in the fundamental state of matter that retains its size and shape without need of a container (as opposed to a liquid or gas).

solos: A piece of music for one performer.

solve: (chiefly law enforcement) A solution; an explanation.

somas: The whole axial portion of an animal, including the head, neck, trunk, and tail.

sones: (acoustics) a subjective unit of loudness for an average listener equal to the loudness of a 1000-hertz sound that has an intensity 40 decibels above the listener's own threshold of hearing

songs: A musical composition with lyrics for voice or voices, performed by singing.

sonny: A familiar form of address for a boy

soots: Fine black or dull brown particles of amorphous carbon and tar, produced by the incomplete combustion of coal, oil etc.

sooty: To blacken or make dirty with soot.

soras: A rail (Porzana carolina) of North, Central, and northern South America.

sorel: A young buck (deer) in the third year.

sorer: Causing pain or discomfort; painfully sensitive.

sores: An injured, infected, inflamed or diseased patch of skin.

sorry: The act of saying sorry; an apology.

sorus: Any reproductive structure, in some lichens and fungi, that produces spores.

sotol: Any of several species of North American desert plants of the genus Dasylirion, of the asparagus family.

sough: A murmuring sound; rushing, rustling, or whistling sound.

souls: The spirit or essence of a person usually thought to consist of one's thoughts and personality. Often believed to live on after the person's death.

soups: Any of various dishes commonly made by combining liquids, such as water or stock with other ingredients, such as meat and vegetables, that contribute flavor and texture.

sours: The sensation of a sour taste.

souse: Something kept or steeped in brine

south: One of the four major compass points, specifically 180°, directed toward the South Pole, and conventionally downwards on a map, abbreviated as S.

spade: A garden tool with a handle and a flat blade for digging. Not to be confused with a shovel which is used for moving earth or other materials.

spahi: (history) An Ottoman (Turkish empire) cavalryman, especially as recruited under a land-based system.

spall: A splinter, fragment or chip, especially of stone.

spang: A shiny ornament or object; a spangle

spank: An instance of spanking, separately or part of a multiple blows-beating; a smack, swat, or slap.

spans: The space from the thumb to the end of the little finger when extended; nine inches; an eighth of a fathom.

spare: The act of sparing; moderation; restraint.

spark: A small particle of glowing matter, either molten or on fire.

spasm: A sudden, involuntary contraction of a muscle, a group of muscles, or a hollow organ.

spate: A river flood; an overflow or inundation.

spats: (often in the plural) A covering or decorative covering worn over a shoe.

spawn: To produce or deposit (eggs) in water.

speak: A low class bar, a speakeasy.

spear: A long stick with a sharp tip used as a weapon for throwing or thrusting, or anything used to make a thrusting motion.

speck: A tiny spot, especially of dirt etc.

speed: The state of moving quickly or the capacity for rapid motion; rapidity.

spelk: (Northern English) A splinter, usually of wood.

spell: Words or a formula supposed to have magical powers.

spelt: To read (something) as though letter by letter; to peruse slowly or with effort.

spend: Amount of money spent (during a period); expenditure.

sperm: The reproductive cell or gamete of the male; a spermatozoon.

spews: To eject forcibly and in a stream

spice: Aromatic or pungent plant matter (usually dried) used to season or flavour food.

spics: A Spanish-speaking person, someone with a Central American or Latino accent.

spicy: Of, pertaining to, or containing spice.

spiel: A lengthy and extravagant speech or argument usually intended to persuade.

spies: A person who secretly watches and examines the actions of other individuals or organizations and gathers information on them (usually to gain an advantage).

spiff: Attractiveness or charm in dress, appearance, or manner.

spill: A mess of something that has been dropped.

spire: The stalk or stem of a plant.

spirt: To cause to gush out suddenly or violently in a stream or jet.

spite: Ill will or hatred toward another, accompanied with the desire to irritate, annoy, or thwart; a want to disturb or put out another; mild malice

spitz: Any of several Nordic breeds of dog such as the Pomeranian or Samoyed

spivs: A smartly dressed person who trades in illicit, black-market or stolen goods.

splat: The narrow wooden centre piece of a chair back.

splay: A slope or bevel, especially of the sides of a door or window, by which the opening is made larger at one face of the wall than at the other, or larger at each of the faces than it is between them.

spoil: (Also in plural: spoils) Plunder taken from an enemy or victim.

spoke: A support structure that connects the axle or the hub of a wheel to the rim.

spoof: An act of deception; a hoax; a joking prank.

spool: A reel; a device around which thread, wire or cable is wound, especially a cylinder or spindle.

spoon: An implement for eating or serving; a scooped utensil whose long handle is straight, in contrast to a ladle.

spoor: The track, trail, droppings or scent of an animal

spore: A reproductive particle, usually a single cell, released by a fungus, alga, or plant that may germinate into another.

sport: Any activity that uses physical exertion or skills competitively under a set of rules that is not based on aesthetics.

spots: A round or irregular patch on the surface of a thing having a different color, texture etc. and generally round in shape.

spout: A tube or lip through which liquid or steam is poured or discharged.

sprat: Any of various small, herring-like, marine fish in the genus Sprattus, in the family Clupeidae.

spray: A fine, gentle, dispersed mist of liquid.

spree: A merry frolic; especially, a drinking frolic.

sprig: A small shoot or twig of a tree or other plant; a spray.

sprit: A spar between mast and upper outer corner of a spritsail on sailing boats.

sprue: A tropical disease causing a sore throat and tongue, and disturbed digestion; psilosis.

spues: To eject forcibly and in a stream

spume: Foam or froth of liquid, particularly that of seawater.

spurn: An act of spurning; a scornful rejection.

squab: (sometimes attributive) A baby pigeon, dove, or chicken.

squad: A group of people organized for some common purpose, usually of about ten members.

squaw: A woman, wife; especially a Native American woman.

squib: A small firework that is intended to spew sparks rather than explode.

squid: Any of several carnivorous marine cephalopod mollusks, of the order Teuthida, having a mantle, eight arms, and a pair of tentacles

stabs: An act of stabbing or thrusting with an object.

staff: (plural staffs or staves) A long, straight, thick wooden rod or stick, especially one used to assist in walking.

staid: Not capricious or impulsive; sedate, serious, sober.

stair: A single step in a staircase.

stake: A piece of wood or other material, usually long and slender, pointed at one end so as to be easily driven into the ground as a marker or a support or stay.

stale: Something stale; a loaf of bread or the like that is no longer fresh.

stalk: The stem or main axis of a plant, which supports the seed-carrying parts.

stall: A compartment for a single animal in a stable or cattle shed.

stamp: An act of stamping the foot, paw or hoof.

stank: To have a strong bad smell.

staph: Staphylococcus bacteria and the infection it causes.

stars: Any small luminous dot appearing in the cloudless portion of the night sky, especially with a fixed location relative to other such dots.

stash: A collection, sometimes hidden; a reserve.

state: A condition; a set of circumstances applying at any given time.

stats: A mathematical science concerned with data collection, presentation, analysis, and interpretation.

stave: One of a number of narrow strips of wood, or narrow iron plates, placed edge to edge to form the sides, covering, or lining of a vessel or structure; especially, one of the strips which form the sides of a cask, a pail, etc.

stays: Continuance or a period of time spent in a place; abode for an indefinite time; sojourn.

stead: A place, or spot, in general.

steak: Beefsteak, a slice of beef, broiled or cut for broiling.

steam: The vapor formed when water changes from liquid phase to gas phase.

steed: A stallion, especially in the sense of mount.

steel: An artificial metal produced from iron, harder and more elastic than elemental iron; used figuratively as a symbol of hardness.

steep: The steep side of a mountain etc.; a slope or acclivity.

steer: A suggestion about a course of action.

stein: A beer mug, usually made of ceramic or glass.

stela: An obelisk or upright stone pillar, usually as a primitive commemoration or gravestone

stele: Something stale; a loaf of bread or the like that is no longer fresh.

stems: Acronym of science, technology, engineering, (and) mathematics.

steno: A stenographer, someone whose job is to take dictation in shorthand

stent: A slender tube inserted into a blood vessel, a ureter or the oesophagus in order to provide support and to prevent disease-induced closure.

stood: (heading) To position or be positioned physically.

stook: A pile or bundle, especially of straw.

stool: A seat, especially for one person and without armrests.

stope: A mining excavation in the form of a terrace of steps.

stops: A (usually marked) place where buses, trams or trains halt to let passengers get on and off, usually smaller than a station.

store: A place where items may be accumulated or routinely kept.

stork: A large wading bird with long legs and a long beak of the family Ciconiidae.

storm: Any disturbed state of the atmosphere, especially as affecting the earth's surface, and strongly implying destructive or unpleasant weather.

story: A sequence of real or fictional events; or, an account of such a sequence.

stour: (now rare outside dialectal) Tall; large; stout.

stout: A dark and strong malt brew made with toasted grain.

stove: A heater, a closed apparatus to burn fuel for the warming of a room.

straw: A dried stalk of a cereal plant.

strew: (archaic except strewn) To distribute objects or pieces of something over an area, especially in a random manner.

stria: A stripe, usually one of a set of parallel stripes.

strip: A long, thin piece of land; any long, thin area.

strop: A strap; more specifically a piece of leather or a substitute (notably canvas), or strip of wood covered with a suitable material, for honing a razor, in this sense also called razor strop.

strow: (archaic except strewn) To distribute objects or pieces of something over an area, especially in a random manner.

strum: The sound made by playing various strings of a stringed instrument simultaneously.

stubs: Something blunted, stunted, or cut short, such as stubble or a stump.

stuck: To become or remain attached; to adhere.

studs: A male animal, especially a stud horse (stallion), kept for breeding.

stuff: Miscellaneous items or objects; (with possessive) personal effects.

stump: The remains of something that has been cut off; especially the remains of a tree, the remains of a limb.

stunk: To have a strong bad smell.

stunt: A daring or dangerous feat, often involving the display of gymnastic skills.

stupa: A dome-shaped Buddhist monument, used to house relics of the Lord Buddha.

sucks: An instance of drawing something into one's mouth by inhaling.

sudra: A turban or headdress, similar to the keffiyeh, worn by Jewish men in the ancient Near East.

suede: A type of soft leather, made from calfskin, with a brushed texture to resemble fabric, often used to make boots, clothing and fashion accessories.

sugan: A wooden chair with a seat made from woven straw or twine stretched over the frame.

sugar: Sucrose in the form of small crystals, obtained from sugar cane or sugar beet and used to sweeten food and drink.

suing: To file a legal action against someone, generally a non-criminal action.

suint: A substance obtained from the wool of sheep, consisting largely of potash mixed with fatty and earthy matters.

suits: A set of clothes to be worn together, now especially a man's matching jacket and trousers (also business suit or lounge suit), or a similar outfit for a woman.

sulci: A furrow or groove in an organ or a tissue.

sulky: A low two-wheeled cart, used in harness racing.

summa: A comprehensive summary of, or treatise on a subject, especially theology or philosophy.

sumps: A hollow or pit into which liquid drains, such as a cesspool, cesspit or sink.

sunup: The time of day when the sun appears above the eastern horizon.

supra: Used to indicate that the current citation is from the same source as the previous one.

surah: Any of the 114 chapters of the Qur'an.

sural: Of or pertaining to the calf of the leg.

suras: Any of the 114 chapters of the Qur'an.

surds: An irrational number, especially one expressed using the √ symbol.

surer: Physically secure and certain, non-failing, reliable.

surfs: Waves that break on an ocean shoreline.

sushi: A Japanese dish made of small portions of sticky white rice flavored with vinegar, usually wrapped in seaweed and filled or topped with fish, vegetables or meat.

sutra: A rule or thesis in Sanskrit grammar or Hindu law or philosophy.

sutta: A rule or thesis in Sanskrit grammar or Hindu law or philosophy.

swabs: A small piece of soft, absorbent material, such as gauze, used to clean wounds, apply medicine, or take samples of body fluids. Often attached to a stick or wire to aid access.

swage: A tool, used by blacksmiths and other metalworkers, for cold shaping of a metal item.

swain: A young man or boy in service; a servant.

talas: The currency of Samoa, divided into 100 sene.

Examples include mica, selenite and the hydrated magnesium silicate that the term talc generally has referred to in modern times (see below). Also an item made of such a mineral and depending for its function on the special nature of the mineral (see next). Mediaeval writers adopted the term from the Arabic.

tales: Any of several units of measure used in China and elsewhere in eastern Asia, approximately 40 grams.
