vests: A loose robe or outer garment worn historically by men in Arab or Middle Eastern countries.

vetch: Any of several leguminous plants, of the genus Vicia, often grown as green manure and for their edible seeds

vials: A glass vessel or bottle, especially a small tube-shaped bottle used to store medicine, perfume or other chemical.

viand: An item of food eaten with rice.

vicar: In the Church of England, the priest of a parish, receiving a salary or stipend but not tithes.

vicus: A small civilian settlement outside a Roman fort.

vigas: A roughly-made rafter or roof timber, especially in a Latin American village

vigil: An instance of keeping awake during normal sleeping hours, especially to keep watch or pray.

vigor: Active strength or force of body or mind; capacity for exertion, physically, intellectually, or morally; energy.

villa: (plural "villas") A house, often larger and more expensive than average, in the countryside or on the coast, often used as a retreat.

villi: A small projection from a membrane, particularly those found in the mucous membranes of the intestines.

vills: The smallest administrative unit of land in feudal England, corresponding to the Anglo-Saxon tithing and the modern parish.

vinas: A plucked stringed instrument with five or seven steel strings stretched on a long fretted finger-board over two gourds, used mostly in Carnatic Indian classical music.

vinca: Any of several evergreen shrubs, of the genus Vinca, including the periwinkle

vines: The climbing plant that produces grapes.

vinyl: The univalent radical CH2=CH−, derived from ethylene.

viola: A stringed instrument of the violin family, somewhat larger than a violin, played under the chin, and having a deeper tone.

viols: A stringed instrument related to the violin family, but held in the lap between the legs like a cello, usually with C-holes, a flat back, a fretted neck and six strings, played with an underhanded bow hold.

viper: A venomous snake in the family Viperidae.

viral: A video, image or text spread by "word of mouth" on the internet or by e-mail for humorous, political or marketing purposes.

vireo: Any of a number of small insectivorous passerine birds, of the genus Vireo, that have grey-green plumage.

virga: A type of note used in plainsong notation, having a tail and representing a single tone.

virtu: The fine arts as a subject of study or expertise; understanding of arts and antiquities.

virus: A submicroscopic, non-cellular structure consisting of a core of DNA or RNA surrounded by a protein coat, that requires a living host cell to replicate, and often causes disease in the host organism.

visas: A permit to enter and leave a country, normally issued by the authorities of the country to be visited.

vises: An instrument consisting of two jaws, closing by a screw, lever, cam, or the like, for holding work, as in filing.

visor: A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.

vista: A distant view or prospect, especially one seen through some opening, avenue or passage.

vital: Relating to, or characteristic of life.

vitta: A fillet, or garland for the head.

vivat: An utterance of the interjection vivat.

vizor: A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.

vocal: A vocal sound; specifically, a purely vocal element of speech, unmodified except by resonance; a vowel or a diphthong; a tonic element; a tonic; distinguished from a subvocal, and a nonvocal

vodka: A clear distilled alcoholic liquor made from grain mash.

vodun: Any of a group of related religious practices found chiefly in and around the Caribbean, particularly in Haiti and Louisiana.

voice: Sound uttered by the mouth, especially by human beings in speech or song; sound thus uttered considered as possessing some special quality or character

voila: Lo, there it is; see here; ta-da; presto; behold!

voile: A light, translucent cotton fabric used for making curtains and dresses.

volar: Pertaining to the palm of the hand or the sole of the foot.

voles: Any of a large number of species of small rodents of the subfamily Arvicolinae of the family Cricetidae which are not lemmings or muskrats.

volte: A turning; a time (chiefly used in phrases signifying that the part is to be repeated).

volts: In the International System of Units, the derived unit of electrical potential and electromotive force (voltage); the potential difference across a conductor when a current of one ampere uses one watt of power. Symbol: V

volva: A cup-shaped mass at the base of various fungi.

vomer: The vomer bone; the small thin bone that forms part of the septum between the nostrils.

vomit: The regurgitated former contents of a stomach; vomitus.

voted: To cast a vote; to assert a formalized choice in an election

votes: A formalized choice on matters of administration or other democratic activities

vowed: To make a vow; to promise.

vowel: A sound produced by the vocal cords with relatively little restriction of the oral cavity, forming the prominent sound of a syllable.

vroom: The sound of an engine revving up.

vulva: The external female sexual organs, collectively.

vying: To fight for superiority; to contend; to compete eagerly so as to gain something.

wacke: A soft, earthy, dark-coloured rock or clay derived from the alteration of basalt.

wacks: An eccentric; an oddball; a weirdo.

waded: To walk through water or something that impedes progress.

wadis: A valley, gully, or stream bed in northern Africa and southwest Asia that remains dry except during the rainy season.

wafts: To (cause to) float easily or gently through the air.

wager: Something deposited, laid, or hazarded on the event of a contest or an unsettled question; a bet; a stake; a pledge.

wages: (often in plural) An amount of money paid to a worker for a specified quantity of work, usually calculated on an hourly basis and expressed in an amount of money per hour.

wagon: A four-wheeled cart for hauling loads.

wahoo: Acanthocybium solandri, a tropical and subtropical game fish.

wails: A prolonged cry, usually high-pitched, especially as of grief or anguish.

wains: A wagon; a four-wheeled cart for hauling loads, usually pulled by horses or oxen.

waist: The part of the body between the pelvis and the stomach.

waive: To relinquish (a right etc.); to give up claim to; to forego.

wakas: A kind of classical Japanese poem.

waked: (often followed by up) To stop sleeping.

waken: To wake or rouse from sleep.

wakes: The act of waking, or state of being awake.

waler: A breed of light saddle horse from Australia, once favoured as a warhorse.

walks: To move on the feet by alternately setting each foot (or pair or group of feet, in the case of animals with four or more feet) forward, with at least one foot on the ground at all times. Compare run.

walls: A rampart of earth, stones etc. built up for defensive purposes.

wally: To estimate the value of; judge the worth of something.

wands: A hand-held narrow rod, usually used for pointing or instructing, or as a traditional emblem of authority.

waned: To progressively lose its splendor, value, ardor, power, intensity etc.; to decline.

wanes: A gradual diminution in power, value, intensity etc.

wanky: Like a wanker; foolish or objectionable.

wards: A warden; a guard; a guardian or watchman.

wared: To be ware or mindful of something.

wares: (usually in combination) Goods or a type of goods offered for sale or use.

warms: The act of warming, or the state of being warmed; a heating.

warns: To make (someone) aware of (something impending); especially:

warps: To twist or become twisted, physically or mentally:

warts: A type of deformed growth occurring on the skin caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

washy: A wash, an act of washing.

wasps: A member of the dominant American upper-class culture: a white Anglo-Saxon Protestant.

waspy: Resembling or characteristic of a wasp; wasplike.

waste: Excess of material, useless by-products or damaged, unsaleable products; garbage; rubbish.

water: A substance (of molecular formula H₂O) found at room temperature and pressure as a clear liquid; it is present naturally as rain, and found in rivers, lakes and seas; its solid form is ice and its gaseous form is steam.

watts: In the International System of Units, the derived unit of power; the power of a system in which one joule of energy is transferred per second. Symbol: W

waved: To relinquish (a right etc.); to give up claim to; to forego.

waver: An act of wavering, vacillating, etc.

waves: To relinquish (a right etc.); to give up claim to; to forego.

waxed: To apply wax to (something, such as a shoe, a floor, a car, or an apple), usually to make it shiny.

wazir: A high-ranking official or minister in an Islamic government, especially in the Ottoman Empire.

weals: A raised, longitudinal wound, usually purple, on the surface of flesh caused by a stroke of a rod or whip; a welt.

wears: To carry or have equipped on or about one's body, as an item of clothing, equipment, decoration, etc.

weary: To make or to become weary.

weave: A type or way of weaving.

weber: In the International System of Units, the derived unit of magnetic flux; the flux linking a circuit of one turn that produces an electromotive force of one volt when reduced uniformly to zero in one second. Symbol: Wb.

wedge: One of the simple machines; a piece of material, such as metal or wood, thick at one edge and tapered to a thin edge at the other for insertion in a narrow crevice, used for splitting, tightening, securing, or levering.

weeds: Any plant regarded as unwanted at the place where, and at the time when it is growing.

weeks: Any period of seven consecutive days.

weens: To suppose, imagine; to think, believe.

weepy: A sad or sentimental film, often portraying troubled romance, designed to elicit a tearfully emotional response from its audience.

wefts: The horizontal threads that are interlaced through the warp in a woven fabric.

weigh: To determine the weight of an object.

weirs: An adjustable dam placed across a river to regulate the flow of water downstream.

wekas: The woodhen, a flightless bird of New Zealand.

welch: A person who defaults on an obligation, especially a small one.

wells: A hole sunk into the ground as a source of water, oil, natural gas or other fluids.

welsh: To swindle someone by not paying a debt, especially a gambling debt.

wench: (possibly offensive) A girl or young woman, especially a buxom or lively one.

wersh: Insipid; tasteless; delicate; having a pale and sickly look.

whale: Any of several species of large sea mammals of the infraorder Cetacea.

whaps: A blow; a hit; a variation of whop.

wharf: A man-made landing place for ships on a shore or river bank.

wheal: To strike the skin in such a way as to produce a wale or welt.

wheat: Any of several cereal grains, of the genus Triticum, that yields flour as used in bakery.

wheel: A circular device capable of rotating on its axis, facilitating movement or transportation or performing labour in machines.

whelk: Certain edible sea snails, especially, any one of numerous species of large marine gastropods belonging to Buccinidae, much used as food in Europe.

whelp: A young offspring of a canid (ursid, felid, pinniped), especially of a dog or a wolf, the young of a bear or similar mammal (lion, tiger, seal); a pup, wolf cub.

where: The place in which something happens.

whets: To hone or rub on with some substance, as a piece of stone, for the purpose of sharpening – see whetstone.

which: (interrogative) What one or ones (of those mentioned or implied).

whiff: A waft; a brief, gentle breeze; a light gust of air

whigs: Acidulated whey, sometimes mixed with buttermilk and sweet herbs, used as a cooling beverage.

while: An uncertain duration of time, a period of time.

whims: A fanciful impulse, or whimsical idea

whine: A long-drawn, high-pitched complaining cry or sound

whiny: Whining; tending to whine or complain.

whips: A lash; a pliant, flexible instrument, such as a rod (commonly of cane or rattan) or a plaited or braided rope or thong (commonly of leather) used to create a sharp "crack" sound for directing or herding animals.

whirr: A sibilant buzz or vibration; the sound of something in rapid motion.

whirs: A sibilant buzz or vibration; the sound of something in rapid motion.

whist: Any of several four-player card games, similar to bridge.

white: The color/colour of snow or milk; the colour of light containing equal amounts of all visible wavelengths.

whits: The smallest part or particle imaginable; an iota.

whity: A white person, a person of European descent.

whizz: A whirring or hissing sound (as above).

whole: Something complete, without any parts missing.

whoop: A loud, eager cry, usually of joy.

whore: Any person (especially a woman) who has sexual intercourse or engages in other sexual activity for payment, especially as a means of livelihood.

whose: (interrogative) That or those of whom or belonging to whom.

wicks: A bundle, twist, braid, or woven strip of cord, fabric, fibre/fiber, or other porous material in a candle, oil lamp, kerosene heater, or the like, that draws up liquid fuel, such as melted tallow, wax, or the oil, delivering it to the base of the flame for conversion to gases and burning; any other length of material burned for illumination in small successive portions.

wider: Having a large physical extent from side to side.

wides: A ball that passes so far from the batsman that the umpire deems it unplayable; the arm signal used by an umpire to signal a wide; the extra run added to the batting side's score

widow: A woman whose spouse has died (and who has not remarried); feminine of widower.

wield: To command, rule over; to possess or own.

wight: A living creature, especially a human being.

wilco: (radio communications) Used to indicate agreement and compliance.

wiles: (usually in the plural) A trick or stratagem practiced for ensnaring or deception; a sly, insidious artifice

wilga: Geijera parviflora, a small tree or bush found in inland parts of eastern Australia, and grown elsewhere for its drought tolerance and its graceful willow-like weeping form.

wills: One's independent faculty of choice; the ability to be able to exercise one's choice or intention.

wilts: The act of wilting or the state of being wilted.

wince: A sudden movement or gesture of shrinking away.

winch: A machine consisting of a drum on an axle, a friction brake or ratchet and pawl, and a crank handle or prime mover (often an electric or hydraulic motor), with or without gearing, to give increased mechanical advantage when hauling on a rope or cable.

winds: Real or perceived movement of atmospheric air usually caused by convection or differences in air pressure.

wines: An alcoholic beverage made by fermenting the juice of grapes.

wings: An appendage of an animal's (bird, bat, insect) body that enables it to fly; a similar fin at the side of a ray or similar fish

winks: An act of winking (a blinking of only one eye), or a message sent by winking.

wound: An injury, such as a cut, stab, or tear, to a (usually external) part of the body.

woven: To form something by passing lengths or strands of material over and under one another.

wrack: Vengeance; revenge; persecution; punishment; consequence; trouble.

wraps: A sharp blow with something hard.

wrapt: To enclose (an object) completely in any flexible, thin material such as fabric or paper.

wreak: To cause something harmful; to afflict; to inflict; to harm or injury; to let out something harmful; .

wreck: Something or someone that has been ruined.

wrens: Any member of a mainly New World passerine bird family Troglodytidae; true wren.

wrest: The act of wresting; a wrench or twist; distortion.

wrier: Turned away, contorted (of the face or body).

wring: A powerful squeezing or twisting action.

wrist: The complex joint between forearm bones, carpus, and metacarpals where the hand is attached to the arm; the carpus in a narrow sense.

write: The act or style of writing.

writs: A written order, issued by a court, ordering someone to do (or stop doing) something.

wrong: Something that is immoral or not good.

wrote: To form letters, words or symbols on a surface in order to communicate.

wrung: To squeeze or twist (something) tightly so that liquid is forced out. See also wring out.

wryer: Turned away, contorted (of the face or body).

wynds: A narrow lane, alley or path, especially one between houses.

xebec: A small two-masted, and later three-masted, Mediterranean transport ship with an overhanging bow and stern.

xenon: The chemical element (symbol Xe) with an atomic number of 54. It is a colorless, odorless, unreactive noble gas, used notably in camera flash technology.

xeric: Extremely dry, lacking humidity and water.

xoana: A wooden statue used as a cult image in Ancient Greece.

xylem: A vascular tissue in land plants primarily responsible for the distribution of water and minerals taken up by the roots; also the primary component of wood.

xysti: (in Ancient Greece) A long and open portico within the gymnasium.

yabby: A freshwater Australian crayfish of the genus Cherax, especially Cherax destructor.

yacht: A slick and light ship for making pleasure trips or racing on water, having sails but often motor-powered. At times used as a residence offshore on a dock.

yahoo: A rough, coarse, loud or uncouth person; yokel; lout.

yajna: A ritual of sacrifice to the Devas.

yanks: A sudden, vigorous pull (sometimes defined as mass times jerk, or rate of change of force).

yappy: Of a dog, yapping in an annoying manner.

yarak: A super-alert state where the bird is hungry, but not weak, with a trance like state of alertness and ready to hunt.

yards: A small, usually uncultivated area adjoining or (now especially) within the precincts of a house or other building.

yarns: A twisted strand of fiber used for knitting or weaving.

yawed: To turn about the vertical axis while maintaining course.

yawls: A small ship's boat, usually rowed by four or six oars.

yawns: The action of yawning; opening the mouth widely and taking a long, rather deep breath, often because one is tired or bored.

yeans: (of goats or sheep) To give birth to.

yearn: To long, have a strong desire (for something).

years: A solar year, the time it takes the Earth to complete one revolution of the Sun (between 365.24 and 365.26 days depending on the point of reference).

yeast: An often humid, yellowish froth produced by fermenting malt worts, and used to brew beer, leaven bread, and also used in certain medicines.

yeggs: A person who breaks open safes; a burglar.

yelps: An abrupt, high-pitched noise or utterance.

yenta: A woman who meddles in the business of others; a busybody; a female gossipmonger.

yerba: Ilex paraguariensis, a species of holly native to southern South America; or the dried leaves and twigs of this plant, used to make the caffeine-rich beverage mate.

yeses: An affirmative expression; an answer that shows agreement or acceptance.

yetis: An unidentified humanoid animal said to live in the Himalayas

yield: To pay, give in payment; repay, recompense; reward; requite.

yocks: A laugh, especially a loud or hearty one.

yoghs: A letter of the Middle English alphabet (capital Ȝ, small ȝ), in form derived from the Old English shape of the letter g, and used to represent various palatal and velar sounds.

yogis: A devotee or adherent of yoga.

yokes: Frame around the neck, and related senses.

yolks: The yellow, spherical part of an egg that is surrounded by the white albumen, and serves as nutriment for the growing young.

yonis: The vulva or vagina, or a symbol of them, especially as an object of veneration within certain types of Hinduism, Buddhism, and other cultures.

young: People who are young; young people, collectively; youth.

yourn: (obsolete outside Britain and United States dialectal) Yours.

yours: That which belongs to you (singular); the possessive second-person singular pronoun used without a following noun.

youth: The quality or state of being young.

yowls: A prolonged, loud cry, like the sound of an animal; a wail; a howl.

yucca: Any of several evergreen plants of the genus Yucca, having long, pointed, and rigid leaves at the top of a woody stem, and bearing a large panicle of showy white blossoms.

yucky: Of something highly offensive; causing aversion or disgust.

yugas: In Hindu theology, an epoch or era within a cycle of four ages: the Satya Yuga (or Krita Yuga), the Dvapara Yuga, the Treta Yuga and finally the Kali Yuga, with lengths ranging from 432,000 to 1,728,000 years.

yulan: Magnolia denudata, a species of magnolia with large white blossoms that open before the leaves.

yurts: A large, round, semi-permanent tent with vertical walls and a conical roof, usually associated with Central Asia and Mongolia (where it is known as a ger).

zaire: The unit of currency of Zaire.

zakat: Almsgiving, one of the five pillars of Islam.

zamia: Any of various cycads of the genera Zamia and Macrozamia

zaxes: A tool, similar to a hatchet, used to prepare slate for roofing.

zayin: The seventh letter of many Semitic alphabets (Phoenician, Aramaic, Hebrew, Syriac, Arabic and others).

zazen: A form of seated meditation in Zen Buddhism.

zebec: A small two-masted, and later three-masted, Mediterranean transport ship with an overhanging bow and stern.

zebra: Any of three species of genus Equus: E. grevyi, E. quagga, or E. zebra, all with black and white stripes and native to Africa.

zebus: A domesticated ox native to Asia and Africa, having a large fleshy hump on its back and a dewlap (Bos primigenius indicus).

zeros: The numeric symbol that represents the cardinal number zero.

zests: The outer skin of a citrus fruit, used as a flavouring or garnish.

zetas: The sixth letter of the modern Greek alphabet (Ζ, ζ) preceded by epsilon (Ε, ε) and followed by eta, (Η, η); or the seventh letter in the ancient Greek alphabet, in which it is preceded by digamma (Ϝ, ϝ)

zilch: A nobody: a person who is worthless in importance or character.

zinco: A line or half-tone block etched on zinc plate, used in zincography.

zincs: A chemical element (symbol Zn) with an atomic number of 30, a slightly brittle blue-silvery metal.

zineb: An organic fungicide and insecticide sprayed on cereal grasses, fruit trees, etc.

zings: A short high-pitched humming sound, such as that made by a bullet or vibrating string.

zloty: Złoty, the currency unit of Poland, divided into 100 groszy.

zokor: Any of several Asiatic burrowing rodents native to Central Asia, in the spalacid subfamily Myospalacinae, related to the mole rats.

zoned: To divide into or assign sections or areas.

zones: Each of the five regions of the earth's surface into which it was divided by climatic differences, namely the torrid zone (between the tropics), two temperate zones (between the tropics and the polar circles), and two frigid zones (within the polar circles).

zooid: An organic body or cell having locomotion, as a spermatic cell or spermatozoid.

zooms: To communicate with someone using the Zoom videoconferencing software.

zoris: A Japanese sandal made from rice straw or lacquered wood, worn with a kimono for formal occasions.

zorro: A South American canid of the genus Lycalopex, visually similar to (and sometimes referred to as) a fox but more closely related to a wolf.

zowie: An indication of astonishment or admiration.
